re-examined. Is might he James Day that pawned it, but I believe it was George Day.

James Day. I came and asked you if you would take it in—you asked me how I got it—I said I got it in a raffle, and was going to raffle it again—I asked you if you would be a member. Witness, I still believe it was George Day that pawned it.

JAMES DAVIS (police-constable C 90.) The prisoner George Day was put into my charge—I took to the station-house and searched him, and then searched his cab—his sister went with me, who had lost some money, which she gave charge of him for—his sister went to the stable with me, which is in Lancaster-street—I found this box there—I brought it to the station-house, and a female who was given into custody with George on the other charge gave me the key—opened it and found this ribbon and key, which the prosecutor claims, and the license for a cabriolet—I referred to the police reports, and found one of them had been charged with stealing a gentleman's watch—I went and told George Day that I had found them, and asked if I had to take James Day, who was then with the cab, who was I to leave the cab with—he said it was a bad job, and that James Day put the key and ribbon there—he did not say whose box it was.
George Day. I have not been in the stabled above twice—they are my father's

COURT to CHARLES DAY. Q. What is your father's name? A. George Day—he lives at No. 10, Gray's-inn-lane—he has not stables in Lancaster-street near Judd-street—my brother George had stables is Lancaster-street because we could not suffer him in the house—he had the Lancaster-street stables when these things were found—my father had not had any thing to do with him for months—they have quarrelled—I am sure these stables are George Day's and James Day drives the cab for George from these stables—here is my father's card.
GEORGE DAY . There is a license in the box which belongs to my
father, Witness, Yes, he hired a cab for him, because he thought he should work.

George Day. My father hired the cab, and James Day lodgers there and drives it—my father hired the stables with me—he is there every morning, and tales part of the money, and has horses out of the stables when he likes. Witness. My father does not receive any money from him, only the money he borrowed to buy the house—the box George borrowed of my father—George offered me the key and the duplicate of the seal is pledge a few days after it was pawned.
James Day. Q. Have you not been there for hourse when you wanted grain and wash? A. No.

James Day. Q. Did I not stop you a fortnight ago with a horse, and out the rains because you should not have it? A. Yes, that was when I was going for your sister's pigs—this box was had by George Day one evening—he wanted 1l. for the key and the duplicate of the seal—I described the key before I saw it again—it was George that gave me the key in my hand, and I looked at it—I tole him I would not have it, to take it back to the gentleman.
George Day's Defence. It is very seldom I go there—I knew that James Day slept there—I knew nothing of the property—I do not follow the cub trade—I am a trunk maker by trade.

COURT to JAMES DAVIS. Q. Where did you get the information where the seal was? A. From Charles Day—when he heard the key was found in the box, he said it was broken, which it is—he then told me where the seal was.
(Amy Thomas, a shoe-binder, of Burton-street, Cromer-street, gave James Day a good character).

JAMES DAY—
GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Transported for Life.

GEORGE DAY—
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: Third Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

div1.p:
1330.
JOSEPH BOND was indicted
for a misdemeanour.
NOT GUILTY .

1331.
CATHERINE GRIGG, alias Ann Gregory
, was indicted
for an assault.

GUILTY —
Confined Ten Days.

1332.
ABNER BEYAN was indicted
for an assault.

GUILTY —
Confined Three Months.

1333.
FREDERICK ROBUNSON was indicted
for an assault.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Recorder.

1334.
ROBERT WILSON was indicted
for an indecent assault

GUILTY .—
Confined Eighteen Months.

div0.p: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
1335.
THOMAS GORE was indicted
for embezzlement
MESSRS. BODLIUM and CHAMBERS conducted the Prosecution.

ELIZABETH LAMERT . I am the widow of Dr. Abraham Lamert, who carried on business at No. 10, Church-street, Spitalfields. He was a patent medicine vender—the prisoner came into his employ about four years since—he was clerk and assistant—he was authorized to receive money for medicines that were sold, and to make proper entries of them in the book—there was a day-book kept to enter money received from customers for goods sent out, or medicines sold—this is the book (looking at one)in which I have always seen the accounts entered—my husband died on the 4th of March, 18936—on the 19th of May. 1835, I left London, and joined him in Dublin, and continued with him until his death—I am his administratrix—the prisoner has not accounted to me, independently of the day book, for 5s., 3d., received from Zaccheus Hunter, on the 9th of July, 1835; nor for 8s. 9d. received from Alfred Willoughby, on the 22nd of August, 1835—he has never accounted for or paid me the sum of 10s., received on the 19th of October, from Mr. James Knight—two days before my husband's death I authorized my son, Joseph Lamert to obtain the prisoner's account from him.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. This is the book in which the accounts were kept, and in which you have always seen the accounts entered? A. It is the book that was given to me by my son since I returned home—it it the book that was taken from the prisoner when I authorized my son to take the books from him—it is the book I was to have had the accounts kept in, after my departure from London.

Q. Is your first answer a true one, that this is the book in which you have always seen the accounts entered? A. That is the book that was given to the prisoner to keep his accounts in after my departure—I might certainly have said that I saw it—that book was given to keep accounts in after my departure from London—I could not swear that I saw accounts entered in it, because it was given to keep the accounts in after I left London—I could have no motive in swearing it—there has been and examination before the Court of Bankruptcy with respect to my husband's effects, and the prisoner was examined as a witnesses—My husband became a bankrupt in November 1834—I remember after Gore's giving his evi
dence his being sent with a messenger to take possession of some secreted goods, of which he had made a discovery—they were my son's—this might have been a fortnight or three weeks before he was apprehended—I think it was as long as that—after Gore's evidence there was a write for 55l. issued against my son Samual, at the instance of the assignees—I saw Samuel a fortnight ago—he is travelling—I do not know where he is—he set out after Gore's evidence—I do not know any thing about the writ—I have heard of it—he set out after the information I had about the writ—I got this book from my son, Joseph Lamert—I put the greatest confidence in my sons, both before and after mu husband's death.

Q. Upon your oath, with respect to those sons, did you not invoke your vengeance, and God Almighty's vengeance upon their heads? A. I do not recollect that I have—I cannot swear that I have not—no recollec
tion.

I received a letter from the prisoner at the bar, (indeed, more than one or two). saving that my sons were the greatest enemies I had, and he so set the mind of the father and against them, that I believe I repbied with irritated feeling, being incensed at such disobidient conduct—all the letters I had at my husbands's death, I delivered over to my sons—I had destroyed several—the prisoner wrote me a letter, saying that one son would take the bed from under me, and the other acted very badly; and the letter I wrote denouncing my children, was in consequence of a letter of Gore's—I am the mother of these sons—the letter I received was in great cause the reason of my writing as I did; and it was in consequence of my eldest son getting married and his father being too ill to come to his marriage, which was one cause of setting me against him—Mr. Gore's letter and my son's marriage, and little family affairs, was the cause of my being alienated from my sons—the two brothers were not friends for some time—it was not to prejudice the Jury that I said it was Goer's letter that alienated me from my sons.

Q. Is not the cause still kept back purposely by you from the Jury? A. The prisoners's letter and my son's marriage without the consent of his father, and little family matters were the cause of it—there might be other causes with the father—to the best of my belief these are the causes with myself.

Q. Was it not in consequence of a letter from your son, Sarswel Lamet, written with his own hand to you to Dublin, that you did it? A. Indeed it was not—I do not recollect ever receiving such a letter.

Q. Then if you wrote to Gore that you had received a latter from your son Samuel, and that while breath remained in your frame the character of its contents would never be erased from your memory—is that true? A. Well, I did—I do not know whether the sight of my own letter has brought it to my remembrance—I did write that letter (looking at it)—I heard at the Magistrate's of letters being burnt belonging to Gore—I heard Joseph swear before the Magistrate that be burnt some—I was not paying any attention to what he said—I cannot tell what letters my son said he burnt—I did not think this letter was burnt, when I said I was paying no attention—I cannot tell what letters were burnt—I did not hear from Joseph that he had burnt some letters I had written to Gore—I heard Joseph say he had burnt some letters in Gore's possession, but I do not know what they were—that was before Gore was taken into custody—he did not tell me he had burnt papers as well as letters—he said they were letters from patients to his father, and different things, and as there was going to be a sale on the premises, be thought they had better be burnt—I cannot tell when I wrote the letter to Gore, denouncing my children—it was in August, I believe.

Q. Was it not what you considered the base conduct of Samuel, in a letter from himself, that caused you to write that letter? A. I do not recollect any letter from him—I know the letter from the prisoner was the great means—Samuel's letter and the prisoner's together might have caused my denouncing him—I do not recollect the contents of my son's letter now.

Q. Did you ever say, that while breath animated your frame the cha
racter of Samuel's letter would never be erased—that to all the world you would show the infamous manner in which he threatened to reduce to the street his unfortunate parents—but that you never would acknowledge yourself a parent to such an unnatural tiend—did not forget that? A. No.
Q. Did you say to Gore "He says, if I do not remit 10l. or 15l. by

return of post, that without any further notice, he will sell off all our furni
ture to pay himself"—did you forget that? A. No, I did not—I acknow
ledge having received a letter from my son—my sons were continually threatening to sell me up, if I did not repay the money we owed—Samuel threatened to come to the house and take the property by force, and sell it—both might have done so—I say Samuel, I did not mean to exclude Joseph—they might have both done it—I do not know—I did give Gore directions, if he dared to enter his father's house, or to touch any article, to eject him by law immediately. Dr. lamer's affairs were in a very bad state—I do not know that Miss Blits, the housekeeper, was obliged to pawn her clother, to support the current expenses of the household—she showed me the duplicates, but she did not say it was to pay the household expenses—I do not know whether it was for the household expenses or herself—I never told the prisoner to keep money which he had received to pay up the arrears of his salary, which the embarrassed state of the firm would not enable me to do—it might be so, but I do not remember it—all monies that he was authorized to receive in the shop business, he was desired by my late husband to enter in the book—he always wrote that he did not get money enough to pay up the arrears of his salary—I have sent him money, not to pay other per
same but I have to pay Miss Bilts—I have not written to the prisoner to shot up the house, and to sell the things, that I recollect—the furniture was to be left in the house—the furniture was not mine—I do not know of his removing any property—I do not know whether it was the custom of my husband and the prisoner to pot down on bits of paper, the sums they received in town and country, and at certain chronological times to enter them in the book—I travelled with my husband, he kept a book, but he past down person's names and residences on papers—he might have put down suns he received also—I cannot swear that he did not.

Q. Was there nothing removed before the bankruptcy from your hus
band's house? A. Ten or eleven months age, Dr. Lamert gave to his son ten or twelve very old chairs, a table, and a few little things; these things were seined at my son's house; and the gentleman of the Court came down, and went through all our house—a great many things were pointed out by Mr. Gore that did not belong to us—on looking over the inventory, they were all there—they came back and searched my trunk—the prisoner said I had a box of jewels; and all they found in my trunk, was a little locket and some seals—Gore has been three or four years in the employment of my husband—these letters are all in my own hand-writing (looking at them.)

MR. BODKIN. Q. You have been asked whether the bankruptcy did not take place in November, 1834? A. Yes; it was; and in February, 1835, that my husband obtained his certificate—I do not know whether the fur
niture was removed before the certificate was obtained—I was summoned to attend the Bankruptcy Court some time in March last, about the 23rd—Gore appeared as a witness, and I was summoned to answer it—my hus
band died on the 4th of March, and I had returned home about three days before I was sommoned—it was alleged that things had been removed be
fore the bankruptcy, and Gore was examined as a witness on that occasion—he had remained in our service from November, 1834, to March, 1836, without saying any thing about it—on my return from Liverpool, I and my son expressed great surprise at the small returns said to have been made by the business—Gore represented, from time to time, that they were not sufficient to pay his wages—when I returned I think they were sufficient—Mr. Isaacs,
who had been clerk to my husband many years, attended to the business.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON, Q. There is a charge of 5d. 3d. from Zaccheus Hunter; was that mentioned before the Magistrate? A. Yes, it was all stated—the prisoner was not with me in Dublin on the 7th of July—I think he left on the 1st.

MR. BODKIN, Q. Was there a house full of furniture at the time of the bankruptcy? A. Yes, very elegant furniture—my son Samuel bought and paid for it, at the value which it came to, by the person sent down by the court to value it—it was valued. I think, as 198l.—there were eight old chairs, a table, and a pair of bed-steps, given by my husband to one of my sons—these were the things that were seized as the property of the creditors after my examination—they sold for 5l. for 5l. 14s—I never was acquainted that there was a write out against my son, till I heard Gore my so at the office at Lambeth-street—we never knew it till that moment—I cannot say whether the early part of this book had been torn out—it looks like it—this book was for the prisoner to enter what he received from customers after I left London in May—there is nothing in this letter that has the slightest reference to these sums of money.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did you not on the 2nd of February last, receive from the prisoner an account of the sums paid and received? A. I do not recollect it—I cannot swear whether I have such an account to the 2nd of February or have not.
COURT. Q. Or any time this year? A. Not to my recollection.
Q. Had he any authority to pay himself his wages from the time you went to Ireland? A. Not that I recollect.

JOSEPH LAMERT . I am son of the last witness. In March last I re
ceived instructions from my mother to go to the prisoner—I went about the 2nd or 3rd of March—my mother was at Liverpool, with my father—I said the prisoners I had instruction to receive all books and papers, and that my father was dangerously ill—I requested him to give up the books and papers—amongst others I got this book—the prisoner came in, and asked me what authority I had to take it—I told him I had authority and showed him a letter written by an assistant of my father, I believe, and signed by my mother—I have not that letter, nor I cannot tell what has become of it—it was addressed to my brother and myself—I told the pri
soner I had taken the books by the authority contained in that letter, and asked whether this book was correct, as it appeared only to he made up to the 2nd of February—he said, "There are only a dozen of pills to go down, and I belive that will make it correct, "or something to that effect—that was all he said—I have looked through the book—it begins on the 23rd of May—there is no entry of either of these suns in it.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Can you tell me where your brother Samuel i? A. He is in the country—I believe in Liverposh—I am not positive—he went away about three weeks or a month ago—I do not know whether it was before or after the prisoner was taken—it might have been within a week of it—I do not live at my mother's—I have an establishment of my own—my brother's is in Drury-lane—that has closed—he is on his travels—he has been away about three weeks—he has been about three or four years in business, and about twelve months in Drury-lane—I am a chemist and druggist, in the Minories.
Q. Shortly before the 2nd of last February. had you been upon good or

best terms with your father and mother? A. I cannot exactly say—we were not till friends—there was a sort of coolness between me, and my friends, and parents, but not till terms—I do no know that I did allege that they owed me money—I think they did—I have a doubt about it—I do not recollect writing for the money—I will not swear I did not—I did not write continually, to dun them for it—it was a month before the 2nd of February that I wrote—I did not write that I and my brother would go to my father's and mother's house, and threaten to sell it up—I never kept of any thing of the kind.

Q. Upon your oath, did you not go to the house of your father and mother, at a time when you were quarrelling and complaining of each other? A. I was at their house—I did not think it required their consent—I had not been forbidden the house—they had not complained to me of my unfilial conduct towards them—I never heard from the prisoner that I was described in my mother's letter as that wicked young man who would be subject to a higher power than theirs for my unfllial conduct to them—I never heard it from Gore, nor from any other source—I had not reason to believe that my father and mother were bitterly incensed against me—there was a coolness arising from money lent—it might be about 50l. or 60l.—but between relations, having lent money, I thought I ought to be paid it—the money was lent at various times before and after the bankruptcy—I cannot tell for what purpose—I believe my brother bought the furniture of the assignees—I went to the house on the 3rd of March, and found Miss Blits and the servant—I took a variety of letters out of a closet—I did not take a 50l. bill of exchange, to my knowledge—I took a variety of papers—it is impossible for me to tell you any particular items—having taken so many I cannot tell you whether I have taken that bill—there were one or two of the prisoner's memorandums—I will not swear there were not twenty—I burnt one or two letters of the prisoner's—I did not burn any memorandums, nor a bill for 50l—I did not find a bill for 50l., receipted—all the papers were burnt—they were confidential letters, addressed to my father in business, of old dates—there were some letters addressed to the prisoner by my mother—I examined some—I scanned over them—I will not swear I examined them all—I do not recollect that the prisoner cane in and said, upon finding his papers being burned, "Now I have nothing to say, now I am ruined"—I cannot swear he did not—I did not say, when I burnt his papers, "Now he will have nothing to shew"—he asked me whether I had burnt his letters, or any letters—I said there were a variety of memorandums, which could be of no use, as we were going to have a sale—I did not run out of the house with the letters in my hand, pursued by the prisoner—my brother did not take them—I sweal they were never removed from the house.

Q. When you found the prisoner bad arrived, you having got there in his absence, did you forbid the servant to let him come in? A. No—I do not think I did—I will swear I did not, nor did my brother in my pre
sence—I do not know the name of the servant—I did not cram the papers into my hat first—I do not know whether I took the bill amongst two or three hundred papers of no earthly use in keeping.

MR. BODKIN. Q. You say they were letters from patients? A. Yes—four-fifths of them were confidential letters—I looked at the letters from my mother—I am confident they did not allude to this case—I took no letters that were not referable to his business as a servant—I took no private papers of the prisoner's—I looked at the two letters my mother sent—they
did not refer to monies he had received in business—at that time I was not aware of any deficiencies on his part, nor had I looked at the books.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did these letters from your mother contain two or three sides? A. They contained two or three.

RICHARD MACLEAN . I was porter to the late Mr. Lamert for eighteen years—it was my business to carry out medicines ordered from him to the customers—Mr. Hunter lives in Blackfriar's-road—on the 7th of January, 1835, I received 5s. 3d. or 5s. 6d. from him—I paid it over Mr. Gore when I got home—I took a bill and receipt which the prisoner gave me—on the 19th of October I received 10s. from James Knight, and gave it to the prisoner—he gave me 6d. for my trouble.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did Rebecca Blits live in the house? A. Yes—I always gave the money to Mr. Gore—I have never paid money to Blits—I cannot tell the day I paid it to the prisoner—what I received from Hunter I received in July—I remember my master's bankruptcy—I lent a hand in removing the goods—I cannot say when it was—whether it was within a week of the bankruptcy—it was within a week—there were some chairs and boxes, and a trunk—Mr. Gore gave them to me—I think my master and mistress were there—I think Mrs. Lamert packed the trunk—the fenders and tables and chairs were removed to Charlotte-street just by where Samuel lives—I went with them with: cart—I cannot say to whose house it was—it was in the afternoon—I can
not say whether it was winter or summer—it was rather dark.
MR. BODKIN. Q. Were these the things that were afterwards sold for 5l.? A. No; I do not know that they were sold—I cannot say how much they were worth—I was employed by Mr. Gore.
ZACCHEUS HUNTER . I live in Webber-row, Blackfriars. I do not know Mr. Lambert's porter—I did not pay this 5s. 3d.—I have got a receipt—my petty cash-keeper is not here.
ELIZABETH LAMBERT . I do not believe this receipt to be the prisoner's handwriting.
ALFRED WILLOUGHBY . I have a receipt for 8s. 9 d. paid to the account of Mr. Lambert on the 22nd of August, 1835—I did not pay it myself.
ELIZABETH LALBERT . This is the prisoner's writing "8s. 9d., received T.G." as he usually used to receipt the bills.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. At the date of that Miss Blits was living in your husband's house? A. I believe she was.
JAMES KNIGHT . I live in King-street, Blackfriars—I remember a sum of 10s. being paid to the porter of Mr. Lambert—this is the receipt takes at the time, I believe.
ELIZABETH LAMERT . This is Gore's writing.

Prisoner's Defence. The real object of this prosecution against me is for the express purpose of invalidating evidence given by me, and to be given by me before the Commissioners of Bankruptcy—a quantity of jewels and valuable things were secreted by me under the direction of the bankrupt, and the prosecutrix in particular—a fellow clerk gave notice, and I was summoned to give evidence, and when upon my oath was obliged to give conscientious evidence which was the means of recovering these goods and jewellery and other things, and it is to be proved whether my evidence will enable the Commissioners to get a sum of 55l. obtained by Samuel Lamert—it will be proved that Joseph and Samuel Lamert came to the house during my absence—that they had gone over the house, and Joseph had put my letters, correspondence, and accounts into his hat—I went to the cupboard

where they had been kept, and they had taken my papers, and left Robecca Blit's paper which were close to the side of mine—Mr. Lamert has stated that he had authority from his mother—I knew he had not—he produced a letter from Mr. Issac
I said I would not attend to that: but the moment they produced their mother's written authority, I said I would go into the account with them—I went to the closet and missed my accounts; Joseph Latnert was down in the water-closet with them in his hat reading them—I went and told him they were of the greatest possible importance to me, and one bill of 50l. I had paid only a few days before—he stated they were in a little box sealed up—I ran to the box and cut the string—they were not there—I ran back and told him, and insisted upon having my letters—the two brothers went out with my letters in their hats—I followed them out think
ing to go to the magistrate for advice—I overtook them and passed them both—I turned my head and they had returned to the house—I went to the house and rang four times, and not being answered, I jumped over the kitchen rails, and got in at the kitchen window, the servants said they had orders not to open the door till the letters were burnt; and Joseph Lambert took me tot he ashes and showed me the ashes of the letters, and he said to Rebeccs, "You are a witness that I burnt them."
NOT GUILTY .

1336.
THOMAS GORE
was again indicted for embezzlement.
(MR. BODKIN conducted the prosecution.)

JOSEPH LAMERT . I left town for Liverpool, my father being ill, on Friday evening, the 4th of March—before I left I saw the prisoner in the afternoon, between two and three o'clock—I said, "Is there any thing to go down; have you had any orders?"—he said there was only a down a dosen of pilla to go down, and there were no orders—I left town—I afterwards saw the prisoner on the 15th or 16th of March—I had told him to put down upon paper any orders he might have had during my absence, and them I asked him if he had any orders—he said, "Nothing, except the dozen of pills"—he has never accounted for 6l. received from George Jones, assistan's to Mr. Sutton, of Bow Church-yard.

ELIZABETH LAMERT . My husband died on the 4th of March, as Liver
pool—the prisoner has not accounted for 6l., received on the 4th of March, from Messrs. Sutton.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You have had a Mr. Issacs in your employ since your husband's death? A. Yes; and he was with us a long time before.

Q. Has not the prisoner, since your husband's death, come to you to account for certain same received, and you refused to hear him, because Mr. Issac was not at home? A. Never; the prisoner called at the house but did not say it was to settle accounts—I have refused to see him, because my son told me, that when he gave him the bills, he said he had accounted for every thing but one dozen of pills—I refused to see him—I never received a message that he wanted to account with me—he called twice at the house—I do not know what he called for—he said he wished to see me—he told his message to Mr. Issacs in the back parlour, and Miss Blits brought it to me—I said I would see him some other time—I do not recollect that she said he wanted to see me for the purpose of settling his accounts, but I will not swear that she did not—my husband died at a quarter before four in the morning, on the 4th of March—my son
Joseph gave me this book about the 15th or 16th, when I returned—the prisoner has had no opportunity of looking at it since.

GEORGE JONES . I was assistant to Messrs. Sutton, of Bow church-yard, in March last—when we want goods, we sent a written order by one of our men—I put a paper out in front warehouse on the 3rd of March, and I believe we did receive some goods from Mr. Lamert—I do not know—I paid for them on the 4th of March, to the prisoner, and have his receipt for them—6l. was the money paid, for six dozen of Scarlett Pills.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What time did you pay it? A. I cannot say; I believe it was after twelve o'clock.
Witness for the Defence.

REBECCA BLITS . I remember hearing to Mr. Lamert's death—I was the housekeeper when Mrs. Lamert went to see her husband—I was there before his death a long time—I remember, after the 4th of March, Mr. Lamert sending me for the prisoner—I went to him, and he came—she sent for the express purpose of settling with Mr. Gore—he came at the time Mr. Issacs happened to be at home—I told Mrs. Lamert he was come, in obedience to her direction—she said she could not see him then.

MR. BODKIN. Q. I believe you are on very intimate terms with the prisoner? A. No—I never quarrelled with him—I was very friendly with him—I lived in the house with him when Mr. and Mrs. Lamert west away—I was then on friendly terms, but not more than before.
NOT GUILTY .
There were two other indictments, on which no evidence was offered.

div0.p: Third Jury, before Mr. Justice Park.

div1.p:
1337.
JOHN CARTER was indicted
for burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house, of
John Glover, at Little Ilford, Essex, about the hour of one in the night, on the 6th of April, with intents to seal, and stealing therein, 3lbs. weight of cigars, value 50s.; 2 coats, value £4; two handkerchiefs, value 10s.; 5 shillings, 30 pence, and 60 half-pence, his goods and monies: 1 coats, value 20s.; 1 umbrella, value 5s.; and 1 hand
kerchief, value 7s., the goods of
William Webb.

ELIZABETH GLOVER . I am the wife of John Glover, and live at the Coach and Horses, at Little Ilford, in the parish of Ilford in Essex. On the 6th of April I went to bed at eleven o'clock at night—I fastened the house up at eleven, but our lodger was a after me—my husband had gone to bed before that—I was called up next morning about a quarter before six o'clock by a person who was going by the house—I got up came down stairs—I found the bar-door wrenched open, and the lock lying on the floor—I am certain I had locked it the night before, and I had the key in my pocket—I missed 3lbs. of cigars from the bar, and 120 half-pence, 60 penny pieces, 5s. in silver, and six silver tea-spoons—I am quite positive they were all there when I went to bed over night—I also missed three great coats, two neck-handkerchiefs, and a silk umbrella, from the her parlour when I had seen them the night before—I saw the prisoner a few days previous to the robbery—I served him with beer at our bar about eleven o'clock in the day—he was not above a quarter of an hour in my presence—I am certain of him—I have since seen the umbrella which belongs to William Webb, our lodger.

WILLIAM WEBB . I reside in London, but occasionally, lodge at the prosecutor's house, and did so on the night of the 6th of April—I went to bed about half-past eleven o'clock, and was the last person up—I did not un
fasten any of the doors or windows after the prosecutor went to bed—I left my umbrella, great coat, and neck-handkerchief, in the parlour—I was awoke at a little before six o'clock in the morning—it was then light—I should say, the sun was about rising at that time—I think it was about a quarter of an hour before six o'clock, as near as possible—I was awoke by a vio
lent knocking at one of the windows, upon the floor I sleep on—I presume it was one with a stick—I got up, and missed my property.

THOMAS SHELSWELL . I am a constable of Lambert-street. In conse
quence of informations, I took the prisoner in Elbow-lane, Shadwell, on Sunday the 11th of April—in his room, and found the umbrella, which I now produce, there—I asked him whose it was—he said, it belonged to the woman below—I supposed he meant the woman who kept the house—I was going down stairs to her, and he called me back, and said, "It is of no use; in fact, the umbrella is my own"—on putting my arm through a a hole in the ciling of his room, I found a bunch of skeleton keys, a crow-bar, an old screw-driver, a dark lantern, and a pistol—the prisoner said to me directly, "You have sprang my plant, "meaning, we had discovered where he concealed things—I afterwards applied the crow-bar to the prose
cutor's bar-door, which had been forced, and found it correspond with the marks on it.

WILLIAM WEBB
re-examined. I know this umbrella is mine—I broke the stick the first day I used it—I know it from that, and many other circum
stances.

ELIZABETH GLOVER
re-examined. The money amounted to 10s. 6d—the tea things and sugar-tongs were worth 15s—I paid 1l., 15s., for the cigars—I do not know the value of the coats—one cost 3l. a very little while ago.

Prisoner's Defence. I bought the umbrella in White-chapel.
GUILTY of breaking and entering, but not of burglary.

1338.
JOHN CARTER was again indicted
for burglariously breaking, and entering the dwelling-house of
Charles Barrett, at West Ham, Essex, about the hour of two in the night of the 1st of April, with intent to steal, and stealing therein, 1 coats, value 2l.; 1 umbrella, value 10s.; 1 tippet, value 5s.; 1 cap, value 2s.; 1 handkerchief, value 2s.; 2 collars, value 1s.; and 1 spoon, value 5s., his goods; and 1 umbrella, value 1l. 3s. the goods of
James Barrett.

CHARLES BARRETT . I live at Chopham farm, West Ham, Essex. On Friday, the 1st of April, I went to bed about half-past eleven—I was the last open up—I looked into the parlour, which was afterwards broken open, and saw that it was fastened—I did not fasten it myself—I was dis
turbed in the night, about ten minutes or a quarter past three o'clock, while it was dark, by a noise—I have a wife and three children, a male and two female servants—I did not get up on hearing the noise as I thought it was the servant going away with a load, which he does about four o'clock—I was called about a quarter of an hour before seven by the servant, Han
nah Davis—it was light then—I went down stairs and found the shutters broker open in the room which I had seen fast—the shutters, were quite open—I missed a great coat, worth 15s. or 16s., two silk umbrellas, a fur tippet, a woman's cap and two collars, a tea-spoon, and several small
things, of very little consequence—all the things were worth between 3l. and 4l.

HANNAH DAVIS . I am servant to the prosecutor. I got up on Satur
day morning, the 2nd of April, at a little after six o'clock—I was the first down—when I got down stairs I found the hail door open, which open into a front yard—they had broken into the parlour and gone out that way—I am certain I fastened the parlour shutters the night before—I missed a tea-spoon out of the store-room, and also the things my master has spoken of—there were several marks of dirt on the window sill and the carpet, as if some body had got in there.

JAMES BARRETT . I live in London. I went to my cousin's the pro
secutor, on a visit, on Sunday, the 27th of March—I only staid there for the duty—I left a silk umbrella there, which I have since sea at Lambeth-street.

THOMAS GEORGE SIZER . I am in the employ of Lawrence Kennedy, a pawnbroker, in High-street, Shadwell. I have an umbrella which was pawned by a female named Sarah Johnson, for 8s.—I knew her before—I do not recollect her by any other name—it was on Saturday, and I think in the afternoon.

BENJAMIN PRITCHARD . I am connected with the police. I went to the prosecutor's house, after the prisoner was taken into custody, to examine the shutter of his house, and brought away a part of it, which I now produce—I compared it with the crow-bar, and it tallies with the marks on it.

THOMAS SHELSWELL . On Wednesday, the 11th of April, I went to Elbow-lane, Shadwell, and found the prisoner there; and in a hole in the ceiling of his room, I found this crow-bar, and other implements—I shewed the crow-bar to Pritchard—I found, on the bed, the duplicate of an umbrella, pawned for 8s., at Kennedy's, No. 184, High-street, Shad
well, on the 2nd of April, in the name of Sarah Johnson—I asked him whose property it was—he said it belonged to him.
(Umbrella produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY of breaking and entering, not burglariously. Aged 19.
Transported of Life.
There was another indictment against the prisoner.

1339.
JAMES BARREGAN and
SAMUEL RILEY were indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of April, 1 necklace, value 5s., the goods of
Charles Tansley, from the person of
Amelia Tansley.

JAMES HENRY MARYBANK . I am a shoemaker, and live in Church-street, Deptford. On Friday, the 8th of April, about five minutes after five o'clock in the afternoon, I was looking out of my shop window, and saw the two prisoners standing on the opposite side of the way, looking down at Miss Tansley—Barregan took the neckalce from the child's neck—the other prisoner stood by, looking out, about a yard and a half from Berre
gan—he stood still for a moment, and Barregan ran away—Riley ran away soon afterwards—he appeared to be looking at Barregan while he took the necklace—they were looking each other is the face—the little girl was
between them—the child ran home and called Mrs. Tansley—she came out, and I told her of it.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Why did you not follow them? A. I had slippers on, and overall trowsers, and no coat, handkerchief, or hat—there was nobody passing by—I did not call out—the glass of my window was down—I saw them distinctly—I did not know them before—I went in pursuit, at last, and found the prisoners, and a third person—they were secured, but no necklace was found on them—when I saw them first, they stood opposite my window, looking at the girl—they walked a little further on them, and one stood on the curb-stone, and the other against the house—the little girl looked up at Riley, and Barregan put his hands and took the necklace off—I saw them searched about half an hour after the Becklace was taken—I remember a man calling on me soon after, about this business—I told him Mrs. Tansley did not wish to prosecut
or, and I did not wish to go forward as evidence.

Q. Did you say you could do something for him unless you were moved? A. No; I swear that—I said I though the man was at the office on the Satur
day—I might have said I knew what he had come about, and would not an
swer him any questions, as he had been talking to me about the matter be
fore—I though he came to me to know the particulars, and I told him he knew the particulars, as I thought he was at the office on Saturday, and he said he was not—he did not use the word. "compromise"—I told him he wished he had not come to me, for then he would have seen we did not wish to prosecute—because Barregan's sister came with the man, crying, but we were compelled to come, and I must state the truth.

MARY ANN TANSLEY . I am the wife of Charles Tansley, and live in Church-street, Deptford. My daughter Amelia, had a coral necklace on, worth 5s.—she is about four years old, or rather more—she had no recol
lection of the prisoners.

JAMES MURRAY (police-constable R 151.) On Friday afternoon, the 8th of April, about half-past five o'clock, the prisoners were given in charge to me, by Maybank, in Church-street—there was a young man in their com
pany, and when I took hold of the prisoners, he went away, and took no notice of me—I called him back, and he came back—I found no necklace.

JERRSMIAH RUSSELL . I am shopman to Mr. Moore, a grocer, No.31, Pitfield-street, Hoxton. I was in company with the prisoners on Friday in Easter-week—I have known them from their infancy—I started from London with them, with the intention of seeing a friend at Greenwich—I was walking three or four yards from them—I remember their being taken into custody, and I went to the station-house with them—they did not attempt to take any necklace at all—I was not taken into custody—I was searched at the station-house because I was with them—they could not have taken a necklace from any body without my seeing them.

COURT. Q. What time did you leave London to go to Deptford? A. About three o'clock, as near as I can recollect—we were on the right-hand side of the archway—they were apprehended at the end of Church-street about a quarter of a mile from Maybank's. and about twenty minutes after five o'clock—it was ten minutes after five o'clock when we were on the rail-road, when we gave our tickets up—we did not go within 100 yards of Maybank's shop—we did not stop any where—we walked on the right-hand side of the rail-road, and Maybank's is one the left-hand, through the archway—the prisoners were taken on the right-hand side of Church-street—one part of the railway goes very close to Maybank's house—we came on the railway to go to see Jones, at Greenwich college—we never went under the archway—we could not be near Maybank's—we were at the corner of Church-street, in the Broadway—I came from Holborn—one of the prisoner is a shoemaker, and comes from Saffron-hill, and the other is a printer, and comes from very close to the spot—we had a holiday that day.

JOHN THOMAS . I am a boot and shoe maker, and live in Peter-street, Clerkenwell. On Friday in Easter week I happened to go down to Dock
head, and at the top of Church-street I saw two boys looking at a bill—it was near about five o'clock—I saw a little child—one of the boys was con
siderably taller than the other—I saw the tall one snatch something from the child's neck, which I considered was a necklace, and run away with it, and the other soon followed—it was near the station-house—I did not follow them, being lame from an accident I have received—I afterwards heard of two boys being taken up for this robbery, and came to Newgate to identify them—I saw the prisoners—they are not the boys who committed the theft.

COURT. Q. How came you to Newgate? A. Because I saw this robbery committed, and not being able to follow them, I went to several streets, thinking to see them, to have them taken, but I could not, and returned home—I did not know Barregan before this transaction—I first saw him in Newgate—I did not know Riley before—I do not know whether either of them live in Clerkenwell—I never heard it—I went to Deptford by the rail-way that day—I got there about half-past four o'clock—I got into Church-street just before five o'clock, as near as I can guess—I had no watch with me—I was never in Deptford before, and walked into Church-street just for a ramble round the place—I did not tell any of the shopkeeper in the street what I had seen—I should know the persons again who took the necklace—they went under the arch-way towards the rail road—they went down Church-street in front of me—I gave no alarm—there was no one by at the time—I went to Newgate of my own accord, to give evidence against them if they were the right people—the prisoners did not ask me to go.

Q. How did you know the prisoners were in Newgate? A. I was in company, and said I saw this robbery committed, and one of my acquaint
ancee, named Phillips, who lives at Chelsea, said, "There are two taken up for the robbery, by the name of Barregan and Riley, and committed to Newgatee"—I put down the names, and went to Newgate and saw the prison
ers, and to my surprise found they were not the two who committed the robbery—I had not seen the two who committed the robbery before—they had not come down by the rail-road with me—one of the parties had a drab coat on, and the other a corduroy jacket—the tall one was nearly five feet seven inches—I cannot say how tail the short one was—I did not notice what coloured neckcloth the tall one had on.

Q. How came you here as a witness, how did you know the trail was coming on? A. I found the father of Riley out after I saw them in New
gate, in Saffron-street—I do not know the witness Russell—I have known him since the 24th of April—on the Sunday I called on Riley—I did not go there with him—I never saw Russel at Riley's—I have only seen him in Court, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday—I never saw him before Monday—I was never at his house, nor he at mine—I never met him at any place—I found out Riley's father by his son's directions.
WILLAIMS BEADLE . I am a fur-skin dresser, and live at No. 4 Saffron-street,

about one hundred yards from Barregan—I have known him about three years—I went to Maybank's house to speak to him—Riley's father gave me his direction—he told me he did not wish to come forward unless he was required—he said he wanted nothing to say to me, that he had seen me before—I had not been to the office, and when he found out his mistake, he related the circumstances of the case to me—he said he saw one of the prisoners take the necklace, and he was sorry for it—I said I knew them to be respectable—he said, "I have lived in Deptford five years, and have my living to get, and if I do anything wrong, I must leave, Deptford altogether"—I do not know Thomas, or where he lives.

JOHN THOMAS
re-examined. Q. How did you get admission to New-gate? A. By passing as the father of Riley—I found I must pass as some relation in order to see them—I passed at the gate as Riley's father—I tried to get in as his uncle, and they would not let me in; and I tried as no relation at all, and they would not lot me in.

J.H. MAYBANK re-examined. Q. Describe exactly the direction the two persons, you saw took from your shop? A. They went up Church-street, towards the Broadway—that would lead through the archway—the rail-road crosses Church-street—it was in Broadway I gave them in charge—they must have passed under the archway to get to where I saw them.

JURY. Q. How long was it before you got out and followed them? A. About a quarter of an hour—there was no difficulty in going the dis
tance in that time—I went twice that distance—I saw them distinctly run to the archway—Barregan ran straight on, and Riley stood at the corner of the arch, and looked back—I have no doubt of them whatever—they were taken, about a quarter of a mile from the archway—there was no man standing in the street at the time the robbery was committed—I have heard Thomas's evidence—there was no man standing near the spot.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. There could be no man on your side of the street without your seeing him? A. Not at the distance I could see—I opened my door directly after, and there was nobody—the train of carriages comes down every half-hour I believe—it does not pass my door—I lost sight of the prisoners for about a quarter of an hour—I live about a mile and a quarter from Greenwich Hospital.
JURY. Q. Did you see the prisoners take the necklace from the child's neck? A. Yes—I could not go out in my overalls.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1340.
GEORGE RAINSLEY was indicted
for stealing on the 25th of April, 1 pair of shoes, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
William Cunningham.

SUSAN GUNNINGHAM . I am the wife of William Cunningham, who keeps a clothes shop in Church-street, Greenwich. On the 25th of April I missed a pair of shoes which hung outside the window—I know nothing of the prisoner—these are the shoes.
WILLIAM SPENCER . I am a pawnbroker. I produce the shoes which were pawned on the 25th of April, by the prisoner, in the name of John Rainsley.
Prisoner's Defence. At the time he says I was in his shop, I was on London-bridge.

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined One Month.

1341.
GEORGE HUGGET was indicted
for an unnatural assault.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Twelve Months.
First Jury before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1342.
MATTHEW ANDERSON was indicted
for feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Henry Wade Smith, on the 16th of April, at Greenwich, and stealing therein 1 glazier's diamond, value 30s. the goods of
Robert Hyde Aish.

ROBERT HYDE AISH . I am a glazier, and live at Mr. Smith's, at Royal-hill, Greenwich, I work for him. I left off work at six o'clock on Satur-day evening, and put the diamond into a little drawer in the shop—I went away, and returned on Monday morning, and it was gone—it is worth 30s.—I do not know the prisoner—he had no right to be on the premises.

CHARLES WILLIAMS . I am a pawnbroker. This diamond was brought to me by the prisoner on the 18th of April, and I stopped it, the prose
cutor having been to me in the course of the day—I sent for him, but he was not at home—I told the prisoner it was stolen—he said he found it—I said he had better come again.
Prisoner. I never was at your home. Witness. Yes, I kept you at the shop till the evening—the prosecutor did not come home—I let you go, and told you to come in the morning.

WILLIAM COLLINGS . I received information, and got a description of the man that offered the diamond go pledge—I went in pursuit, and found the prisoner with another man, named Barrett—I said to the prisoner, "Who gave you the diamond you offered to pledge at Mr. William's?"—he said, "Barrett"—I said, "Where did he get it?"—he said, "Of Heath"—I said, "How came Heath by it?"—he said he gave a wild rabbit for it—I then asked Barrett—he said all that he knew about it was, that he had seen it in the hands of Anderson.

WILLIAM WOODGATE . I am in Mr. Wade's service. I was going up Royal-bill, on the 16th of April, and saw Henry Heath, nearly opposite my master's premises about eight o'clock in the evening—I did not see the prisoner there.

Prisoner's Defence. I got it from Barrett; and Heath was convicted last month for stealing a horse-cloth—he brought this diamond and rabbit into the park—Turner and Barrett went to Heath, and asked him to buy a wild rabbit—he said he had no money—they asked what he had got—and he gave me 2d. and a wild rabbit for the diamond.
NOT GUILTY .
Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1343.
SARAH SMAILL was indicted
for feloniously receiving, on the 28th of April, of an evil-disposed person, 2 candlesticks, value 8s.; 2 basins, value 11s.; 2 ewers, value 1s.; 1 salt-collar, value 1s.; 6 cups value 10d.; 6 saucers, value 10d.; 5 plates, value 2s.; 2 tea-pots, value 4 milk-pots, value 6d.; 5 mugs, value 1s. 9d.; 1 box, value 1s. 2d.; and 1 fountain, value 1s.; the goods of
Joshua Freeman Strang.

JOSHUA FREEMAN STRANG . I am a china and glass-dealer, living at the corner of Richmond-street, Woolwich. These five tea-cups and other articles, produced by Butterfill, are all mine—I missed them on thee morn
ing of the 28th, when we were about to fill up the vacancies for goods sold on the preceding days—they are all mine—but this little mug I could not swear to.

THOMAS HADDEN . I am in the employ of Mr. Strang. I noticed, on two days in April, two children, daughters of the prisoner, who are ten and twelve years old, were loitering about—my master had missed things before, and desired me to watch them—we found a mug on one off them.

JOSEPH BUTTERFILL . I am a constable. Between eight and mine o'clock on the evening of the 28th of April, I went to Mr. Strang, find
ing he had two children in custody who had robbed him of different articles—he was not at home—I waited while Mrs. Strangg sent for him—he came with two other persons, and we thought proper to go to the residence of the prisoner, who occupies a room as a weekly tenant—there is a garden, but I do not know whether she claims it—it belongs to that house—I believe she has access to it, and goes through it—I told her I had her two children in custody, respecting the things that they had taken from Mr. Strang's—I named the candlestick and some cups and saucers—finding the children were detained, she stated that she had placed the things in the gar
den—she went with me into the garden, and pointed out the place, and there we found the things—she begged that I would have mercy on her—I told her it was out of my power to do any thing but take her to the station-house till the following day.

WILLIAM CAMPION . I am a constable. I went to the prisoner's house where she lodged, and told her we should be under the necessity of taking her into custody—she said she would take us to where the things were—she took us into the garden, and pointed out one spot where we found these things—I saw the ground had been dug in another part, and there found the other things—she is in distress, I believe she has not a thing to lie upon.
NOT GUILTY .
Sixth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1344.
WILLIAM BOWDELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of August, 1 handkerchief, value 2s.; the goods of a person unknown, from his person.

RICHARD TOZER (police-constable A 120) On the 1st of August I was in front of Greenwich Colleg—there was a mob in consequence of their Majesties coming to visit the college—I saw the prisoner with another man—the prisoner gave his name Thompson—I saw the prisoner take the handkerchief from a man, and give it to his companion, named Dobsen—I took them both with assistance to the station-house—the prisoner was remanded—he broke out of the cage, and got away—I do not know what became of the gentleman—he did not appear—the officer went to give something to a person in the cage, and this prisoner and the others who were there knocked the man down and ran away—he was taken a fort
night ago—when the prisoner gave the other man the handkerchief he put it into his hat, and put it on his head—in going to the station, Dubson took his hat off and gave me this handkerchief—Dobson was committed for a month.

Cross-examined by MR. JONES. Q. Had you seen the prisoner before? A. Not to my knowledge—I had known Dobson—this was about three o'clock in the afternoon—I did not see the gentleman afterwards—I do not know that the gave any name to me—I did not hear him—I took the prisoner about half a mile to the station-house—I have been to where he lived—his neighbours were surprised to hear of it, and said he was an honest, hard-working man.
Prisoner. This officer came and took me—he found a handkerchief on Dobson, who was with me, but it never was in my hand.
RICHARD TOZER . I am satisfied that he took it—I had been watching them some time—I knew Dobson.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Three Months.

1345.
CHARLES HARDING was indicted
for stealing, on the 29th of April, 4 chain traces, value 4s.; 2 gate books, value 1s.; and 1 sack, value 1s. 6d.; the goods of
William Morriss.
WILLIAM HURDISH . I live at Lee, in Kent, and am foreman to Mr. William Morriss. This is one of his sacks—I missed a great many—the prisoner worked for me a little while at hay-making.

GEORGE HARRIS (police-constable R 158.) On the 29th of April I saw the prisoner in High-street, Deptford, with this sack on his shoulder, turned inside out—I followed him to Flagon-rew, and stopped him—I asked what he had got—he put then sack down, and I found these traces in it.
Prisoner. I told the officer that I had it of a man named Jones, who told me he worked for Mr. Morris.

GUILTY . Aged 41.—
Confined Six Months.

1346.
LUCY SHILL was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of April, 1 quilt, value 2s. 6d.; 2 blankets, value 3s.; 2 sheets, value 3s.; 11 look
ing-glass, value 3s.; 1 tea-kettle, value 9d.; 1 pillow, value 3d.; 1 pil
low-case, value 3d.; and 2 candlesticks, value 2d.; the goods of
John Wilkinson.

MARY WILKINSON . I live in Charles-street, Woolwich; my husband's name is John. The prisoner lodged with me—on Saturday, the 2nd of April, she had been out all night—her husband lived with her, but he was drafted away the Wednesday before—she came home at eleven o'clock, and I asked her for an iron which I had lent her—she said she would go and fetch it, and she did not come back again—I heard a noise in he room between twelve and one o'clock—I thought it was her sister's little girl—I went down—the door was not quite closed—I went in, and missed these things—she did not return—these things are all mine.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

WILLIAM BOWERS . I live in Church-street, Woolwich, and am a broker. I produce two duplicates, which I bought of the prisoner's niece through charity—I gave her 3d. for them—she asked me 6d.—I did not want them—I have repeatedly told her I would have nothing to do with them—I did not buy them with the intention to take the things out—one if for the glass for 1s. 6d., which is not worth the money; and the other a gows for 4s.—the girl was to have them again at ten o'clock—a duplicate of two candlesticks was also bought at my shop, but not by me.

EDWARD JOHN TALBOT . I have one blanket, which was pawned for 1s. 6d., and one blanket and quilt for 2s. 6d.—they were pawned in Fe
bruary—I cannot recollect the person.

HARRIET LUCY COOK . I am the prisoner's niece. I took a quilt from my aunt to the pawnbroker, and I sold these duplicates to Mr. Bowles—I told him I was to fetch them again, as my aunt was going to Blackheath to get some money—she sent me with them—I pledged these candlesticks for 8d., which I took to Mrs. Shill.

THOMAS HENRY MOURE . I produce a duplicate of a blanket, which I bought of the prisoner for 6d.—it was pawned for 1s. 6d.—she stated that she was in great distress, and her husband was going away—I have not seen the blacket—I did not know what it was worth.
WILLIAM THOMAS CHANDLER . I am shopman to a pawnbroker. I have the glass pawned by the prisoner's niece—I believe the prisoner was in distress.
The prisoner put in a written defence, pleading poverty; and stating her intention to have redeemed the articles at a future period.

GUILTY . Aged 34.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury.
Confined Four Days.

1347.
SOPHIA PRICE was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of April, 4 pieces of wood, value 9d., the goods of
John Lawrence.

JOHN LAWRENCE . I am a cooper. I have seen the prisoner twice—I never had any quarrel with her—I never saw her till before the Magistrate—these are the boards taken from the fence of my garden, which was all safe about the 14th of April—I missed them the day after—they are not worth above 3d. or 4d.—some of them do not belong to me.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. This seems rather an old fence? A. It has been up nearly thirty years—we have had a good deal tumble, down, and these might do so,

GEORGE STREAK (police-constable R 133.) On the 14th of April, at two o'clock in the morning, I heard a noise of breaking a fence—I saw a man, and the prisoner behind him, with some wood on her—she said she it up—I left her in custody, and went after the man—he had a bundle, which was shoes—I said, "Come back to your wife"—he said, "Don't notice it; I will give you half-a-crown"—the prisoner resisted, and said she would give me any thing to let her go.

Cross-examined. Q. Do not you think this noise might be from tread
ing on it with the feet? A. I cannot say—I believe they are husband and wife.
NOT GUILTY .

1348.
HENRY HEATHER was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of February, 1 horse-cloth, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
John Breakspear; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

THOMAS TAYLOR . I am groom to Mr. John Breakspear, of Greenwich. I saw the horse-cloth safe in the stable, about half-past six o'clock on the 16th, and missed it on the morning of the 17th, about half-past six o'clock—this is my master's cloth.

JOHN SIZER (police-constable R 103.) On the 20th, the prisoner was in custody on another charge, and I found this cloth round his body—he said his mother gave it him to wear while she washed his shirt.

GEORGE DORSY . I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former Con
viction (read)—the prisoner is the boy.
Prisoner. I took it to putt round my body for a shirt, as I had none on while my mother washed my clothes—I worked about the place, and got in at the left, down the ladder.

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Three Months, the last Fourteen Days solitary; and
whipped.

1349.
SUSAN KALMAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of April, 56lbs. weight of potatoes, value 4s., the goods and monies if
Wil
liam Garrett .

WILLIAM GARRETT . I live in Church-street, Greenwich, and keep po
tatoes in a bury in Coom-farm-lane. I missed a great many, and em
ployed a man to watch them—I know my potatoes—these are them.

WILLIAM WEBLING . I am a labourer. On the 19th of April I went is watch the potatoes—I saw the prisoner and three more come down to the bury—I went up, and caught the prisoner picking the potatoes out of the bury into her lap—I told the Magistrate that—I said I saw her sitting on the side of the bury—that I went there between seven and eight o'clock, and between eight and nine o'clock I saw the prisoner, two others, and a lad, or a man, come down to the bury—I waited a little while, and then went down, and saw two girls in the straw, and the prisoner sitting on the side of the bury, taking the potatoes into her apron—I told her to come to my master, and he would forgive her—he gave her into custody.
ROBERT LEE . I am a police-constable. I took the prisoner, and have the potatoes.
The prisoner pleaded distress, and received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 42.—Recommeded to mercy.—
Confined Four Days.
Fifth Jury before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1350.
WILLIAM LONDON was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of May, 1 pair of boots, value, 6s., the goods of
Daniel Bain.

DANIEL BAIN . I am a gunner in the Royal Artillery. The prisoner was my comrade—I went out on the 7th of May, at a quarter before nine o'clock, to drill—my boots were standing by my bed-side, in the barrack-room, No. 82—the prisoner is married. and is out of the barracks alto
gether—I missed my boots at half-past twelve o'clock, when the man was going to clear out the room, and reported the circumstance—the boots were brought back at a quarter past four o'clock, and laid on my bed by some
body—I did not see them brought.

MAREBROTHER FLEMING . I am sergeant-major of the 9th Battalion. On Saturday, the 7th of May, it was reported to me by Corporal Watkins, that Bain had lost his boots—I called the cook of the room, and in conse
quence of what he said, I spoke to the prisoner, pointed out the situation in which he stood, and told him it was a pity an old soldier like him should commit himself, and I was bound to make him a prisoner—he said he would much sooner give up his own regimental boots, than have any dis
grace—I said there was no occasion for that, if he was innocent—he said he would sooner do it, then have his name brought in question—I asked if his son had been about the barracks—he said, "Yes"—he was sent to the guard-room—I after wards sent two officers with him to his own house, where they saw his son and his wife—his son was examined before the commanding officer, on Sunday, and said that he himself watched his opper
tunity, and went into the room and stole the boots, while the cook was gone out with the ashes—the son was taken into custody, but there was no bill found against him.

HENRY WATKINS . I am the corporal. On Saturday, the 7th of May, Bail told me the boots were gone—I reported it to the sergeant-major—he told me to take the prisoner into custody—I did so—the prisoner said, if his boy had been and taken them, if he was allowed a quarter of an hour, he would go and get them out of him—I was afterwards sent to the pri
soner's house, and his wife and son were there—they denied all knowledge

of them—I was sent again with the prisoner, and then the prisoner's wife and son denied all knowledge of it—the boy said, when he was brought before the commanding officer, that he had stolen them, and his them in the sand-hole, and his mother was sent to get them.

WILLIAM BAIN . I was a gunner. I was cook at No. 82 room—I sa✗ the boots in the room—I gave the men their breakfast, and then went to get their dinners—when I came back the prisoner came in, and a bom
bardier asked him to come and help him to clean his room, which he did—the prisoner had no boots in his possession, that I saw—I saw the boots there when he came in, and in about a minute and a half after he was gone I missed them—I saw no one else in the room—I never saw the prisoner's son in the room that day—I am not positive that I did not see him go by the passage, but the was not in the room that day.
Prisoner. I am quite innocent—my boy acknowledge he did it—I know it would be the ruin of me to do it.
NOT GUILTY .

1351.
MARY SAWYER, alias Frampton
, was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of April, 1 watch, value 3l.; 1 chain, value 9d.; and 1 key, value 3d.; the goods of
George Rudram.

GEORGE RUDRAM . I am a gardener. I met the prisoner at Greenwich, on the 24th of April, at a public-house—we had some gin—she took me to a hour—I gave her 1s. to pay for the room, and 2s., 6d. for herself—I hug my clothes on another bed head in the room—she asked me for 1 1/2d. to get some gin—she went to my clothes, and book my watch out, and ran out of the room—I gave the alarm on soon as I could—being a stranger, I did not know which way to go—I called the policeman—I am quite sure she is the person.

BRIDGET SULLIVAN FITZGERALD . On Sunday night, the prosecutor and prisoner came to my house—I did not hear them go up—stairs—I was asleep, but after the prisoner was gone, the prosecutor came down, and he awoke me, and said the girl had robbed him—I did not see her in the house at all.

JAMES WILLIAM ALLUM (police-constable R 89.) I received informa
tion, and took the prisoner in Cut-throat-lane—I have never found the watch.
Prisoner. He said at one time he gave me the watch, and then he said that I stole it.

GEORGE RUDRAM . No—I did not. BRIDGET SULLIVAN FITZGERALD. The man told me that he gave her the watch to take care of—I told that to the Magistrate—the prosecutor told it to me, and Mr. Look wood was in the room—the prosecutor appeared sober—I was in bed, and did not see them come in—I was asleep till he came down and awoke me.
Prisoner. He gave me the watch, and told me I might keep it—I put it down, and do not know what became of it.
NOT GUILTY .
Sixth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1352.
HENRY LINCH was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of April, 1 pair of half-boots, value 3s. 6d.; and 2 handkerchief, value 1s.; the goods of
William Cunningham.—2nd COUNT stating them to be the goods of
Susan Cunningham.
SUSAN CUNNINGHAM . I am the wife of William Cunnigham, we keep a clothes-shop in Church-street, Greenwich. On the 8th of April, about

eight o'clock in the evening, the prisoner came with a Greenwich pri
soner to buy a waistcoat—there was a woman in the shop when they came in—there were four handkerchiefs pinned up, and just as the woman left the shop I saw them drop from the gown to which they were pinned—asked the prisoner to pick them up, and when he did so there were only two instead of four—"Bless me. "said I, "there were four—I pinned them up just this minute"—he said the woman that woman that went out of the shop took them—I called my mother from the other side of the way, and went out to fetch the woman—I came back presently, and my mother said she did not believe it was the woman who had the handkerchiefs, but it was this boy, and he had got something else as well—he was just then gone out—the college-man had been trying on waistcoats, and the prisoner had been hold
ing his clothes the while—I looked on the counter and missed a pair of half-boots, marked No. 3—I then went after the prisoner and the college man—I saw the college-man and spoke to him, and he brought the prisoner to my shop the next day—I gave him in charge—he had one of my hand
kerchiefs round his neck, the other in his trowsers, and he had to him the duplicate of my boots.

BETSY WILES . I am the mother of the witness. I was left in charge of the shop—the prisoner had the college-man's coat and waistcoat on his arm—he put them down and tried on a jacket—I said, "It is too large for you—there is not one will fit you"—he then put on his own jacket and went to the counter where the boots were—he turned his back to me and saw something sticking out inside his jacket—I was flurried and looked out—I saw my daughter coming—the prisoner then went away and turned the corner—my daughter came in and missed the boots.

MICHAEL QUIN . I am a labourer. On the morning of the 9th of April I was working in Thames-street, Greenwich—I heard a cry of "Stop thief," and this young fellow ran by—I stopped him and took him to the prosecutor's shop—this ticket of the boots and this handkerchief were found in his trowsers, and this other handkerchief round his neck.
EDWARD CARTER . I am a pawnbroker, and live in Bear-lane. The prisoner pawned these boots on the 8th of April, for half-a-crown—he said they were his brother's—I had seen him before.

JOHN DYER (police-constable R 109.) I took the prisoner into cus
tody.

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Whipped and
Confined Two Months, the last Fourteen Days solitary.

div0.p: THOMAS FRY, DENNIS REARDEN, and BENJAMIN CASTLE were attainted of burglary. See page 1.
Second Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

div1.p:
1353.
DANIEL PESTELL and
GEORGE WILLIAMS were in
dicted for
stealing, on the 20th of April, 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
Charles Miller, from his person.

CHARLES MILLER . On the 20th of April, between eleven and twelve o'clock in the day, I was stopped in Surrey-street by a man, who said "You have had your pocket picked"—I felt, and my handkerchief was
gone—I gave my address to the person—I cannot say when it was taken—it was in my possession when I was at the City gas works—this is it.

WILLIAM POUND . I am a cordwainer. On the 20th of April I was coming over Blackfriar's-bridge, and observed the prisoner watching a gentleman very narrowly, which made me notice them—they were in com
pany—I followed them—they followed a gentleman a little way over the bridge—he walked very fast—the prosecutor came along, and they followed him—he stopped on the bridge to speak to another gentleman, and they stopped till he went on again—they then followed him, and made several attempts to pick his pocket, till they got to the corner of Stamford-street; and, as a coach passed, Williams picked his pocket—I immediately went and told the gentleman that he was robbed—he said he was, and gave me his address, but would not go back with me—a young man who was with me kept them in sight, I went to his assistance, and saw them go back, and go over the bridge again—I followed them down Bridge-street to Far
ringdon-street—they there saw a policeman, and separated—my friend went and told the policeman—I went and collared Pestell, and the hand
kerchief produced was found in his hat at the station-house.

THOMAS JACOCK . I was in company with Pound, and saw the prisoners on the bridge together—we followed them—I saw Williams attempt to pick the prosecutor's pocket once or twice, and at the corner of Stamford-street, he succceeded in getting the handkerchief, and handed it to Pestell—they ran down Stamford-street—Pound went to inform the prosecutor—I stood at a distance, and saw them come from Upped Ground-street—I followed them over the bridge, and had them secured in Farringdon-street.
ALEXANDER NELSON . I am a policeman, Williams was taken into custody at a quarter to twelve o'clock the same day.
Williams' Defence. I left my master in James-street, Queen-square, and went to a newspaper-agent in Fleet-street, to take a ream of paper, and as I returned was taken in charge.

PESTELL—
GUILTY .† Aged 18.

WILLIAMS—
GUILTY †. Aged 17.
Transported for Fourteen Years.

1355.
MARY MURPHY was indicted
for stealing on the 27th of April, 2 sheets, value 4s.; 1 bed-ground, value 1s. 6d.; 3 towels, value 1s.; 1 pillow-case, value 6d.; 1 cap, value 5s.; and 3 handkerchiefs, value 2s., the goods of
Elizabeth Warner her mistress; and 1 coat, value 3l. 10s.; 1 waistcoat, value 20s.; and 1 pair of boots, value 20s., the goods of
George Burchell.
MR. CHAMBERS conducted the Prosecution.

ELIZABETH WARNER . I live at No. 40, Baron's-buildings, Waterloo-road, Surrey. On the 26th of April, I was in want of a servant—the pri
soner offered herself, and I engaged her—Mr. George Burchell came to sleep at my house that night, and delivered me his coat, waistcoat, and a pair of boots to be cleaned—I desired the prisoner to brush them in the morning—I got up at a quarter after seven o'clock, and the prisoner was then gone—the door was on the latch—I missed all the articles stated in the indict
ment, besides Mr. Burhcell, clothes—I saw the prisoner again on the 28th, of Union Hall, in custody—I received no character with her—I took her solely from her account of herself—she said she had been two months in the hospital ill.
Prisoner. It was an indecent house for me to go to—she keeps a house

for ladies and gentlemen, and unfortunate girls—she told me if I would walk the streets, she would find me in clothes—I said, no, I would not amnd she said, if she could not punish me one way, she would another: and the gentleman she says lodges at her house, lives with her. Witness. These is not the slightest truth in it.

JANE BUTT . I live at No.3, Baron's-buildings, Waterloo-road. On the morning of the 27th of April, a little before seven o'clock, I saw the prisoner in Webber-street, near the Riding-school, about five minutes walk from the prosecutor's house—she had her apron full of something, and two cap-strings, hanging out of it—I said to her, "Did you get the situation?"—she said, "Yes, and thank you"—she had come to my mother's shop and inquired for a situation, and we recommended her to the prosecutrix.
Prisoner. Q. What kind of Cap-strings were they? A. Two strings with edging—I could swear to them.

GEORGE BEARCHELL . I am a policeman. I apprehended her on the 27th, about nine o'clock in the evening, in the tap of the Duke's-hand public-house—Mr. Burchell gave her in a charge—she said; "Do not handle me, I will go with you quietly, I know what you want"—I took her to the station-house—I have not found the things.

Prisoner's Defence. I said I would not go without he told me what he wanted of me—I did not know what it was about—the prosecutrix know I was going to leave her—it is a house of ill-fame—when she found I would not stay, she said she would take my liberty from me.,

GUILTY .*Aged 18—
Transported for Fourteen Years.

1355.
HANNAH BARRETT was indicted
for feloniously receiving of a certain evil-disposed person, on the 7th of May, 33 napkins, value 1l. 13s., the goods of the
Earl of Aberdeen and others, well knowing them to be stolen; against the Stature, &c.
CHARLOTTE ROSS . I am house-keeper at the Aathaeneum, in Pall Mell, Several table napkins, which I had the charge of, were lost—they have been traced to various pawnbroker.

JOHN DODDS . I am a pawnbroker, and live in Mount-street. I have two parcels of napkins, which were pawned at various times by the prisoner—all within fifteen months—two parcels, of six and four napkins, were pawned on the 30th of April and the 7th of May.

WILLIAM BALLARD . I am an officer. I was employed to make inquiry respecting this property—I issued some hand-bills, and received information from the last witness; who said they were taken in from Penfold, No. 9, Isabella-street, Oakley-street, Lambeth—I went there, and apprehended Mrs. Penfold, and her husband, who had been a waiter at the Athenaeum club—at that time I saw the prisoner in the front parlour—she lodged with Mrs. Penfold—I asked the prisoner if she had seen any napkins there, and whether she had every pledged any—she said she had not: that she had pawned a gown and shawl for Mrs. Penfold, but never any napkins—I left Mrs. Penfold in care of Goddard, while I went to look for her husband—I directed Goddard to take Mrs. Penfoldd to Bow-street; and there the pawnbroker said Mrs. Penfold was not the person—he described the person to me—I went back to Mrs. Penfold's house—after waiting so me time the prisoner came in—I went out with her, and, in Westminster-road, I said I had cause to suspect she had pawned some of napkins—she said she had not—I said, "I must take you to the pawnbroker's to see"—I took her there, and the directly said,
"How do you do, Mrs. Penfold?"—I said, "Is this the woman who pawned the napkins?—he said, "She is"—she said she had not, or if she had, she did not know it—Penfold and his wife were discharged.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did the Magistrate discharge him, though he had been a waiter there? A. Yes; it was Mr. Halls, I think—there was not sort of evidence against him—were could prove the napkins were in his possession—there were about forty-one found altogether.

JOHN DODDS
re-examined. I do not know Penfold to swear to him—I had seen him—I know him now—I did not before—the address given was No. 9, Isabella-row—I went there, and found Penfold did live there—I always took the prisoner for Mrs. Penfold, because she gave that name.

WILLIAM WATSON . I am butler to the Athenaeum Club, and have been so nearly six years—the Earl of Aberdeen is a member of that club, and a trustee—there are other trustees—I have examined the napkins, and have no hesitation in saying they belong to the club—the name of the club is marked in the damask.

CHARLOTTE ROSE
re-examined. I believe all these to belong to the members of the club.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know Penfold? A. Yes; he was discharged from the club on suspicion of stealing a gold watch from a gentleman—these napkins have been found since that, but I lost them two years age—some of them were missed before his discharge.

Prisoner's Defence. I am guilty of pawning them, but innocent of knowing they were stolen—they were given to me by Mrs. Penfold as her own property—I always gave her the money and the tickets, the moment I returned to her house—both Penfold and his wife, at the first examination, begged me not to acknowledge to it, or I should have done so—both thee butler and Mrs. Rose heard him beg me not to acknowledge it.

WILLIAM WATSON
re-examined. Q. Did you observe whether Penfold and his wife made a communication to her at the office? A. My back was turned to them—I heard a whispering—I cannot say what it was about.

1356.
HANNAH BARRETT was again indicted
for feloniously receiving, of a certain evil-disposed person, 8 napkins, value 8s., the goods of the
Earl of Aberdeen and others, well knowing the same to be stolen; against the Statute, &c.
HENRY CRICK . I am servant to Barnett and Dickens, pawnbrokers, I have two napkins, pawned in the name of Penfold—I know the prisoner by coming to the shop—I cannot say she pawned them.
JOHN DODDS . I am a pawnbroker. I produce six napkins pawned by the prisoner in the name of Penfold.
Cross-examined. Q. She gave you Penfold's proper address? A. Yes; Penfold was held to bail, to answer any charge that might be preferred.

WILLIAM BALLARD . I am an officer. I questioned the prisoner if she had pawned any napkins—she denied it, and denied it to the pawnbroker, and also at the officer, when Penfold and his wife stood at the bar.
WILLIAM WATSON . I am butler at the Atheneum—Lord Aberdeen and other are trustees—I know these to be the property of the club.
Third Jury before Mr. Justice Littledale.

1357.
JOHN MITCHELL HALL was indicted
