for stealing, on the 19th of April, at Putney, 9 sovereigns, 1 half-sovereign, 1 half-crown, 20 shilling, and 14 sixpences, the monies of
Leonard Boyten, in his dwelling-house.

LEONARD BOYTON . I keep a beer-shop at Roehampton, in the parish of Putney, in Surrey. On the 19th of April the prisoner came to my house about twelve o'clock in the day, and remained till about half-past four o'clock, and paid for it about five o'clock—he used to work at Squire Gordon's as a labourer, and then he used my house—he had not been to my house since he left "Squire Gordon's which was about Christmas time—I had nine sovereigns and a half-sovereign in gold, and 30s. in silver, in different coins, in a box in my bed-room—the gold was in a bag and the silver loose in the box—the box was locked, but the key left in the lock—I had been to it about five o'clock that evening—there was then eleven sovereigns in it—the prisoner at that time was in the top-room—I brought two sovereigns down into the tap-room, and took them into the parlour—I had them in my hand in the tap-room, but I cannot say whether any body could see them—I took them to a man in the parlour, who give me 30s. in silver and half-a-sovereign in change for them—he was a hawker, and was in the habit of giving me change—I immediately took it up-stairs, laid the 30s. in the corner of the box, and put the half-sovereign into the bag, where I had nine sovereigns—there was no silver in the box believe that—about nine o'clock that night I went up-stairs to my bed-room and mis
sed the money—the prisoner had gone out about seven o'clock—I saw him go out of the tap-room into the street, and meet Richard Sawyer in the street—all my money was gone except one sixpence at the corner of the box—I found the key in the lock of the box, but the box-lid was open—the box was standing on the floor—there were some notes, my watch, and different things in it—none of those were gone—the money was not marked—the stair-case fronts the street as you come in at the door—a person coming in from the street could go right up-stairs—there are about eighteen stairs—there is a stair-case on the top of the first stairs, before you get to the room—the prisoner was sometimes at work for three or four months together, at Mr. Gordon's, at other times he was off work for a few weeks—while he was at work he used to come to my house to breakfast and dinner—he was never up-stairs to my knowledge—he was taken about ten o'clock that right, and I saw eight sovereigns and a half in gold, 24s. 6d. in silver, and 4 1/2d. in copper, taken from him.

Cross-examined by MR. ALLEN. Q. You speak about his being at your house about five o'clock, how many people were there at that time? A. One person besides, names Johnson—no other person was in that room—I have a skittle-ground—there was nobody there—there in a pas
sage between the room the prisoner was in and the other room—there was no one in the kitchen—Mr. Case was in the parlour—they were-the only three persons in the house—the prisoners was in the tap-room, which is on the left-hand side of the street door—the bar is behind the sap-room—I had the money in my hand about five o'clock—the hawker gave me change in the parlour, which is the right hand room—I took it up-stair, and the hawker went home—the prisoner paid me about five o'clock for the half-and-half—I have no means of knowing that the money found on the prisoner was mine—I have no recollection of telling the Magistrate
I had no reason to suspect him, but that I heard he had money—the prisoner had been showing money about and I missed mine.

JOHN EDGAR . I am a policeman. On the 19th of April I apprehended the prisoner, between ten and half-past ten o'clock, on the prosecutor's charge, in a hay-loft, over the stable belonging to Mr. Royal, of Rochamp
ton—it is a public-house, and is between two and three hundred yards from the prosecutor's—I searched him, and found on him eight sovereigns, one half-sovereign, one half-crown, 17 shillings and nine sixpence in silver—they were in his left-hand jacker pocket—all in one pocket, the gold, silver and half-pence—I made him no threat or promise—he questioned me, to know where I was going to take him—I told him on suspicious of robbing Mr. Boyton's bed-room of nine sovereigns and some silver, and I was going to take him to the station-house at Wandsworth—he replied, "Take me where you like: do what you like with me, and send me out of this b—country, for I shall do no good in it"—I found on him a key, a knife and part of a comb.

Cross-examined. Q. How did you know where to find him? A. By inquiry—I had no difficulty in finding him in the loft—he was locked up in the stable, and covered up in the third stall, but I found him in the loft over the stable—he had moved—he was drunk and al seep when I found him—he did not say he had taken that place for his bed for the night—while I was taking him to Wandsworth, he said the money was him own, and he had saved it by his industry.

Q. Did not he say, "If you take me to prison, you may as well send me out of the country, for I shall do no good in it afterwards?" A. No; he said as I said before—he did not say he should lose him character by such a charge as this.

WILLIAM CASE . I am a shoemaker. On the 19th of April I saw the prisoner about five o'clock in the afternoon—he came into the parlour at Boyton's, were I was, and said, "Care, lend me sixpence to pay for some beer; I have got plenty of sovereigns; I will pay you again"—I lent it him—he was very drunk.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you known him? A. From a baby—I expressed no surprise at his saying he had plenty of sovereigns, being drunk—I gave him the sixpence to get rid of him—I should have been surprised to see him with sovereigns at that time—year ago I have known him to have sovereigns—he has been out of a work a good deal lately—he has not been in a situation of late years to be possessed of sovereigns, but four of five years ago be might—I believe he is am hones man when sober.

RICHARD SAWYER . I saw the prisoner on the 19th of April, about fifty yards from Mr. Boyton's house, coming from there towards, Roe
hampton village, about seven o'clock in the evening—he asked me to lend him sixpence—I told him I had not get one—he put his hand in his left-hand waistcoat pocket and pulled out a quantity of sovereigns—I did not see how many there were—he said, "I have just made good lab; don't say nothing about it"—he said he had not lobbed for nothing this time—I do not know what he meant by that—I asked him if it was his own money, or whether he was going to pay a bill with it—he told me he had just been and prigged it, and that the man did not know he had got it, and he should not give it him back without he stood some near—he appeared to be very drunk—that was all that passed that evening.
GEORGE ROYAL . I keep a public-house at Rochampion. I saw the

prisoner pass my house about seven o'clock, or a few minutes before—I did not see him again till about eight o'clock, when he returned to my house—he came to the bar, and flashed a lot of sovereigns in his hand—he took them out of his waistcoat pocket, and asked me what he owned me—I told him 18d.—he told me to take it—I told him, if that was him money he should pay me, I should not take it out of his hand—he paid me, and went away.
Prisoner's Defence. It is money I have saved to many months past.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Transported for Life.
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1359.
ANN HOWELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of April, 1 frock, value 3s., the goods of
James Woolridge; and that she had been before convicted of felony.

MARY ANN WOOLRIDGE . I am the wife of James Woolridge, a master builder, and live in Kent-street, Borough. I first knew the prisoner six weeks ago, when she came to char for me—on the 23rd of April I missed a frock and several articles out of my bed-room drawer—she had been at work there that day—I have since found them at the pawnbroker's.

ROSETTA HAWTHORN . I am married. I recommended the prisoner to Mrs. Woolridge, thinking her an honest woman—hearing of the robbers, I went to the Clink to the prisoner, and got this duplicate from her, which I gave to the officer.
PERCIVAL SMALL . I am a policeman. I received the duplicate from Hawthorn, and apprehended the prisoner.
WILLIAM FRAAS . I am shopman to Mr. Rosier, a pawnbroker, in Tooley-street. I produce a frock—I do not know who pawned it—this is the duplicate I gave the person.

JOHN STOREY . I am an officer of the Borough. I have a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I obtained from Mr. Clark (read)—I was the officer on the trial—the prisoner is the person.
Prisoner. I did it through distress—I was left a widow with two small children.

GUILTY .* Aged 41.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.
Before Mr. Justice Coleridge.

1360.
GEORGE LOSCOMBE and
JOHN WEST were indicted for
feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Thomas Spiers, on the 12th of April, at St. Mary, Lambeth, and stealing therein, 11 watch value 2l. 10s.; 2 seals, value 36s.; 1 watch-key, value 4s.; 1 ring, value 6d.; 1 pocket-book, value 5s.; 16 napkins, value 10s.; 2 coats, value 3l.; 1 waistcoat, value 5s.; 3 pair of trowsers, value 30s.; 1 ornaments, value 5s.; and 2 shawls, value 7s., his goods.

THOMAS SPIERS . I live in Lark-hall-lane, Prospect-place, in the parish of St. Mary, Lambeth. On the 12th of April, I went out at rather between than half-past two o'clock—there are two doors in front of my house, and a back-door also—I left nobody at home—one of the front-doors was fastened by a spring-lock, and the other was bolted inside, chained, and locked—I left the one which fastens by a spring, shut—I returned at a few minutes after six o'clock the same day—I unlocked the door which was on the spring-lock, and found the house had been robbed—I found my desk broken open, the lock of it was broken—it was in the back sitting-room,

down-stairs—I cannot say any thing was missing from the desk—the papers were strewed about—I missed my watch from the same room, that had been on the mantel-piece—I went up-stairs and found the drawers all open, and things taken out—they were all ransacked—four china ornaments were taken from the mantel-piece of the front bed-room; and from one back-room, sixteen disper napkins, three silver coins, out of a drawer—two gold
seals, a key, a ring, and one pair of drab trowsers, from the same room—and a great-coat, a dress-coat, two pair of trowsers, and a waistcoat out of the back-room—the lock of the cupboard down-stairs was broken open, we missed nothing from that—I had left all these articles safe—I had my watch in my hand after half-past two o'clock, when I left the house.

JOHN PLUMMER . I live about a hundred yards from Spiers. On the day of the robbery I saw both the prisoners about a hundred yards from my house, very near the prosecutor's house—it was about four o'clock, or a little after—they were holding the fence looking over into the field at the front-part of the house—I went into the garden afterwards, and remained there about twenty minutes—I then saw them pass in a direction towards London, from Mr. Spiera's house—they each had a bbundle, I believe; I know West had one under his left arm, which was next to me by the fence—I am not quite certain that Loscombe had a bundle, neither of them had a bundle when I saw them before—I was about ten yards from them—I could see West's bundle better than the other.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Are you quite sure this was on the day of the robbery? A. Yes; the prosecutor's house lays between the Clapham and Wandsworth roads—I remember hearing of a trotting-match in the neighbourhood—that was on the 11th, and this was on the 12th—I had seen them on the 11th as well, which made me notice them.
COURT. Q. Where did you see them on the 11th? A. In a public-house, and they asked me for the newspaper which made me notice them—they were together then.

JOHN STEPHENSON . I am a policeman. I had heard of Spiers's robbey—I was on duty in Clapham-road on the 16th of April, and saw the prisoners on Clapham-rise together, and having the description of the two men from Plummer, the moment I saw them I walked by them and watched their manceuvres for a considerable time—I then went home and put on my plain clothes and called Plummer, who lived close by me, and came to the spot near where I had seen them before—they had been there for an hour and a half—I sent Plummer on first, and then I went up and took them into custody on suspicion of being the two men, on the Rise, and took them to Clapham station-house—I searched them, and on West found pocket-book, a silk handkerchief, three half-pence, and a penknife—on Loscombe I found a silk handkerchief, a skeleton-key, two latch
keys, a snuff-box, a tabacco-box, and a chisel—he said the skeleton-key was the key belonging to his residence, and the latch-keys belonged to his door at No.36, New-street, Lambeth—I went to the house, but could not open the door with the skeleton key—the latch-key I could open it with, with difficulty, but it was not made for that latch, for the latch was a square one, and this is not a square—one of them does not fit at all—I took Loscombe's hat off and felt round it, thinking there might be something in the lining, but there was nothing in it—I put it down close by the side of him, and am sure there was nothing in it then—I took a black silk handkerchief off his neck and searched that, and put that in his hat, or close to it.
Cross-examined. Q. Is Clapham-rise far from where the robbery was
effected? A. It is half-a-mile from it—the skeleton-key did not open the door at all—I found his residence correct.

WILLIAM GEORGE WORRALL . I am a policeman. I was at the station-house when Stephenson brought the prisoner in—I recollect his searching them perfectly well—I saw Loscombe'ss hat taken off—it was placed on a box close by his side—a person in the room took up the hat—I immediately took charge to it, and there were six skeleton keys in it—that might he minutes after it was first put down—they were tied up in a small piece of calico—I went to the prosecutor's house, and tried the whole of the key and the smallest of the six undid his door very easily indeed.

Cross-examined. Q. Were they examined by you at the station-house A. Stephenson searched them—there were no other prisoners in custody at the time—there was nobody present but the prisoners and the police.

GEORGE VICKERSS . I am a policeman. One Sunday morning some weeks previous to this, (I forget the date,) I saw West in the New Cut, Lambeth—I saw him go into a house at the corner of Isabella-street, and Gibson-street—it was before the 12th of April—I went to that house on the 16th after coming from Union-hall, and having a list of the property lost with me, I searched, and in a small box I found this small seed on the first-floor front room—I shewed it to Mr. Spiers—he described the seal he had lost to me before I showed it to him.
MR. SPIERS re-examined. This pocket-book do not know—this seal is one I lost—it was on a ring with another seal and a key—there is nothing else that I know.

Cross-examined. Q. Is not that rather a common kinds of seal? A. I bought it for gold—I know it is mine—I have seen seals wish the same motto but I never saw one with a green stone like this, nor have I seen one worn like this is, which is white at the top—I remarked that to my wife—I said when I described it that there were red spots on it similar to sealing-wax—I have no recollection of saying there were bits of red stealing-wax on it—the Magistrate said the red marks were not sealing-wax but blood stone—I have had it seven years next August—I told the Magistrate what the motto was, and about the spots, and its being worn.

Loscombe's Defence. I went on this day to see my brother, who lives in a gentleman's service in Clapham-road—there was a trotting match, and we stopped to see it, but it did not come on—we went to the Larkhall public-house and had some dinner—I did not go that way again till Wed
nesday or Thursday, I am not sure which—I did not see my brother then, and went again on Saturday—I have two lodgers, and each have a key.
West's Defence. I accompanied him in the way he had said to see him relative.

LOSCOME—
GUILTY Aged 25.

WEST-
GUILTY Aged 23.
Transported for Life.
Before Mr. Justice Park.

1361.
DAVID HAGGERSTONE was indicted
for the wilful murder of
Harriet Haggerstone.
MR. CHAMBERS conducted the prosecution.

WILLIAM HEDGES . I live in hut built of hay and straw on Merton
common in Surrey. The prisoner and his wife lodged with me them between six and seven months—they were very often falling out, especially when they came to their meals—I have heard the prisoner say to her, "I will make you come under the table like a little dog, I shall be hanged for

you"—I have heard him say that several times—very often on a Sunday, when he was at home from his labour, at dinner time—he told me on Friday the 15th, that he was at work up at the Crown at Merton—that is about four hundred yards from my hut—I was at the White Hart at Merton on Saturday evening the 10th, with my wife; a man named Claridge was there, and almost all the men who work on the iron rail-road, because that is where we receive out money—I received my money about eight o'clock—I saw Mrs. Haggerstone come in between ten and eleven o'clock as near as I can tell—Claridge was there when she came in—the prisoner was not there—she staid there till twenty minutes to twelve o'clock—I heard Claridge ask her to drink with him, and saw her take the pot off the table and put it to her mouth—I cannot say whether she left the house alone, for we all went out of the bar—she came and asked me for a loaf, saying she had no bread for her children, and all the shops were shut up, and I let her have a loaf from my bag—I missed both Claridge and her from the house while I was at the bar—I went out about five minutes after (I dare say), because I stopped to have a glass of rum at the bar—I did not see Mrs. Haggerstone afterwards—I and my wife went to Saunders's beer-shop to pay sixpence which I owed, and while we were in there the clock struck twelve—we left the beer-shop a about half a mile from our hut, down the fields—we went directly home from the beer-shop—when we got home we found the prisoner there lying down on the bed, with his clothes on—his wife was not there—nothing passed between me and him then about his wife—my wife and I went to bed—some time after we had been in bed, I heard voices outside, it was John Green and William Steel—I do not know the time, as I had been asleep—the persons outside said Mrs. Haggerstone was sick—they gave an alarm—they stopped a little while, and said, Mrs. Haggerstone was drowned—they had not left the spot—they remained to see if Haggerstone would go with them—I wanted him to get up and go—I said, "If it was my case, I should go and see about it"—he began crying, and said he could not leave his children and his baby—he had four children, and one of them is mine or ten months old—he did not get up then, and the persons went away—I got up a little after five o'clock on Sunday morning—Haggerstone was still there—he was getting up then to go with Serle and Hart, the constable and overseer—I do not recollect asking him any questions.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. You have spoken of expressions be used; I suppose, at times, men in your class of life quarrel with their wives? A. Sometimes—we do not always live without quarrelling—I cannot tell whether he had been drinking that night or not—I had been drinking a little, but I was sensible that I was going home, and, when I got home, I heard the clock strike—the children were in bed with the prisoner when I got home—Mrs. Haggerstone did not tell me, when she asked me for the loaf, that her husband had just given her 8s. 8d., which ha had received—she had money, for she paid me for the loaf—I did not see what money she had—she had more than what she paid me—the prisoner knew Hart the constable, and Serle the overseer, very well—Claridge is no acquaintance of mine, only he worked on the road with Haggerstone and me—he had been at my house—he came there on Sunday morning, but never came inside the hut—Steel and Green first said Mrs. Haggerstone was sick, and then that she was drowned—they called out to the prisoner and told him so—I cannot say justly at what time I got home—it might be a little after one o'clock

ELIZABETH HEDGES . I am the wife of Williams Hedges—the prisoner and his wife lodged with us for about seven months—they lived on very bad terms together—I have heard the prisoner make use of very bad expressions to her—he often said, "You d—little b—, madam, I'll do for you, I cannot do as I like here, because I am in Mrs. Hedge's house"—he said, "D—you, I will do for you, before long: as I am in Mrs. Hedges's house I cannot do as I like:" and then he said again, "Madam, d—you, I will do for you"—on Saturday, the 16th of April, Mrs. Hag
gerstone went out at a quarter past one o'clock in the day—I was in the White Hart, with my husband, about eleven o'clock at night, and she came and sent in for me, and she then came in with me—I did not see her go out-we staid at the bar till about half-past eleven o'clock—I did not see Claridge go out—I saw him there—my husband and I left the White Hart at half-past eleven o'clock—Mrs. Haggerstone and Claridge were gone when we went away—I was sober—my husband was not—I called Mrs. Haggerstone for some time, when I came out of the house, but got no answer—I afterwards saw her at a little gate, about twenty yards from the White-Hart—nobody was with her—it was between the White Jart and Saunders's beer-shop—she went with me down Merton-rise—my husband and I did not go into Saunders's beer-shop together—Mrs. Haggerstone was with me, but she would not come into the beer-shop—I asked her several times, and left her at the second little post, close to Wise's—that was on her road home—there is a turning to the left, just before you get to Saunders's beer-shop, which would take her home—it does not pass by the well—when we went into Saunders's it struck twelve o'clock, and when we came out it was half-past twelve o'clock—we went direct home—I found the prisoner at home—he was not undressed, but lying on the bed—I said to him, "Davy, is your wife at home?"—he said, "No, Mrs. Hedges, is not she along with you?"—when I went in again, I said, "Davy, my lad, do get up, it is a very dark night, I would get up and go across the fields and look for her"—he said he would see her d—d first: he supposed she was at some of her wh—tricks"—I said to him. "Stop Davy, don't judge her, for it is a dark night"—he said he would see her d—d before he would go outside the doors—I then said to him, "Oh, Davy, don't say so; come my lad, come get up and go and look for her"—he said, "No, I won't; and God send I may hear of her corpse before long"—and then, between sleeping and waking, I did not go to bed for half an hour after—I did not go to sleep when I went to bed—he got up after a bit, and I thought he was going after his wife—I spoke to him, hoping he was going after her—he said, "No; I will be d—d if I do," and said he was going to undress himself to go into bed to his children—he said, "She neither shall by aside of me, nor yet of my children no more"—I said to him, "Davy, come my lad, come"—he said, "No: I would see her d—d before I go out to her, nor shall she enter my house any more"—this was while I was up—I went to bed after that, but could not sleep—I was aroused some times after that, and heard persons come to the side of the bedge—I rose up momestarily and heard what they said—I hallooed to the prisoner two or three times while the persons were outside, "Davy," but got no answer—I said to his eldest daughter. "Mary, is your father awake? wake him up"—he awake, and I said, "Davy, there is something the matter with your wife: do Davy, get up, pray do; I will go with you"—"No," he said, "I will see her d—d first, and I hope I shall see her corpse directly"—I said, "Come get up, I will go with you" and then the men outside said, "Pray do

come, Davy, for Mr. Parsons wishes you to come" (Parsons keeps the White hart)—the prisoner said, "No; I will be d—d if I get up"—the men did not go away for some time—my husband began d—g and swearing at the prisoner, saying "Why do not you get up?"—he said, "No"—then the news came afterwards that she was drowned—the men did not say she was drowned at first, they said she was ill—he was awake when they said she was drowned—he then began to make a howl, and my husband said, "Are you an Irishman?"—he did not get up before the morning—he cried out while howling, "Oh, Claridge, you have done me, Oh, Claridge, you have done me! why did you not stop it? Oh, Claridge, why did you not stop me? I am done it—I am done it—I am done it"—(Mrs. Haggerstone had washed for Claridge)—when he said he had done it, he said, "The devil was with me while I done it—my husband did not hear all this, he was gone to work—he works on the rail-read, and is obliged to go to work on Sunday morning—this was about twelve o'clock in the day—it was at one o'clock in the day on Sunday that he said, "The devil was with me when I done it, &c." and he said it when in bed that night, before he got up—I swoke my husband, and told him of it—my husband always went to work on Sunday morning to repair the new rail-road, because it is out of order—there are six of them at work there on Sunday—it was before the people came to arouse the prisoner that he used the expressions—before Green or any body came, and told him what was done—that is true.

Cross-examined. Q. You have been examined before about this? A. yes; twice before—Claridge was taken up on the 17th, and kept in custody for a week—I was examined before the Coroner on the Monday as this happened on Sunday—my husband was drunk when he left the White Hart—I was leading him house—he was sensible, but fell down a great many times when we came out of the Tom and Jerry—he did not tumble down between the White Hart and Saunders's—I never left him—it would not have been safe to leave him—he was so drunk, he could not stand, and it was so very dark—he went to bed directly we got home.

Q. Had you not some fancy in your head that some mischief would happened to Mrs. Haggerstone? A. No, I has not at all—I had begged her to stop with me, but her answer was "No"—that was at the White Hart—I did not see Claridge and her together, except at the White Hart—I saw that she talked to him once, but I did not see them go out together—the prisoner said, "Is not she with you Hedges?" and complained of her having at her tricks—I recollect perfectly well his saying, God send he might find her a corpse, and I am done it, &c.—both before he got up and afterwards—I told the Coroner of those expressions—I mentioned that he said. "I have done it; I have done it; the devil was with me at the time"—what I said was read over to me, and I put my mark to it.

Q. On your solemn oath, did you say a word to the Coroner about "The devil was with me: I have done it! I have done it?" A. No, sir, I did not—I said it the other day before the Grand Jury—while Claridge was in custody, I did not say a word about it—it is the truth—I have spoken nothing but the truth about what he said—I have see Claridge to day—I did not see him yesterday—I did the day before, here—I did not say a word to him—I have not seen him any where else but here—I will swear that I never saw him at my own house, or near it—he never came down to my place since he was at Merton—I have not seen him in the White Hart Since this business—oh yes, I have, but I never kept his company—I did not make use of the

expression, "God send I many see her corpse directly "before the Coroner the first time—I mentioned it here—it was dropped—it was said, "You have said enough, "and they said they should want me another day—I did not say go up again—they said they should want me another time—I did not say before the Coroner that he said, "Claridge you have done me"—I knew that Claridge was in custody charged with having been guilty of this murder, when I was before the Coroner—I did not say a word of all this conversation before the Coroner—I do not know that I said a word of it till after Claridge was out of custody—I did not say a word of it to the attorney for the prosecutor—Mrs. Haggerstone would not have passed by the well if she had taken the direct road home—it lays quite in another direction—the well is a quarter of a mile or better from our house—I awoke my husband to hear what the prisoner was saying, but he would not hear it—I said to him "Is not it a strange thing that Mrs. Haggerstone should be out so late as this," and he said, "Yes; but I suppose he has done it"—I did not tell the corner that—I was not there when the surgeon was examined—I did not see her body myself—I went to see her on the Sunday morning—I heard that from examination, it was supposed some one had had connexions with her—the constable and overseer came to the prisoner on Sunday morning; but the expressions I have stated were before he went to work on the Saturday morning—that was not about "The devil was with me, &c." but when he turned round to her on the Saturday, he said, "D—n your eyes, when I get you by myself I will make you humble yourself to me like a little dog—d—u you, I would do for you now, and be hanged for you, if it was not for Mrs. Hedges"—and the poor woman cried—I did not say a word of that before the Coroner.
MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Did you mention to Mr. Harding's partner about these expressions? A. Yes; those used on Saturday morning.

COURT. Q. Was you with your husband when he talked to the prisoner in the morning, do you remember the people coming and saying Mrs. Haggerstone was sick? A. Yes; and after that that she was drowned—when the prisoner heard that he cried, and said he could not leave his children and baby, and my husband said, "Oh, I suppose you have done it, that is the reason you will not go."

THOMAS WALLACK . On the night of the 16th of April, I was acting as watchman at Merton. I was in the White Hart about twenty minutes before twelve o'clock—I saw Mrs. Haggerstone about sixty yards from the White Hart, as near as I can tell, between that and Saunders's beer-shop, going towards Saunders's, which is in what is called the Rush—William Claridge was with her—I know his person—he was dressed in a short white round fast—they were stopping in the road, talking together—I could not hear what they said—they were eight or nine yards from me—they were alone—they continued in my sight two or three minutes—Mrs. Hedges then came out of the White Hart, and called Mrs. Haggerstone several times—Mrs. Haggerstone did not make any answer, but still stood there with Claridge, for two or three minutes, till Mrs. Hedges and her husband came up, and then they all four walked down the road together—Mr. and Mrs. Hedges, Mrs. Haggerstone, and Claridge.

ELIZABETH HEDGES
re-examined. Q. Who went with you when you found Mrs. Haggerstone, after calling her, after coming out of the White Hart? A. We went down as far as the Rush together, but I never saw Claridge, I will be on my oath.
JURY. Q. Were the prisoner and his wife in the habit of quarelling when they first came to live with you? A. Yes.

THOMAS WALLACE
re-examined. I know Claridge's person very well—I am quite sure he was one of the four I saw going from the White Hart, towards Saunders's beer-shop together.

MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Did they walk all four near to one another, and appear to be in company? A. They appeared to be in company—Claridge and Mrs. Haggerstone were about a yard or two behind the others—they were all in one company—Hedges appeared to be intoxicated—Mrs. Haggerstone had a loaf under her arm—I just saw them pass me on the road—that is all—I believe Mr. Haggerstone had a bonnet on, but I did not take particular notice—I never saw the prisoner at all that evening—I never saw Claridge with Mrs. Haggerstone before.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. How long would it take to walk from the White Hart to where you first saw there persons? A. Not above a minute, I should think—it was about twenty minutes before twelve o'clock—Mrs. Haggerstone was nearer to me than Mrs. Hedges when Mrs. Hedges called out to her—she could have heard her—she made no answer, but remained with Claridge—I believe Haggerstone was taken up, and afterwards liberated—I do not know how many days he was at large.

COURT. Q. You were very near to Claridge and Mrs. Hedges? A. Yes—I soul think it impossible she could have been there, without seeing Claridge and Mrs. Haggerstone together—they were together—they came up to them—I was examined before the Coroner on the Tuesday after it happened, and Claridge was shown to me there—I am sure he is the man I saw talking to Mrs. Haggerstone.

GEORGE HONE . I am foreman to Miss Paynes. On the 16th of April I lived in a little cottage just by Miss Paynes's—next to the farm-house—I was going home that night, from the White Hart—I had been down there to do some business—I left there as near twelve o'clock as could be—it was about ten minutes after twelve o'clock when I got home—just opposite Saunder's beer-shop there is a turning to the left, which leads to the Winding-shot field, and to the hut where Haggerstone lived—when I got a short way up that lane, I saw a man and woman at a stile on the right-hand side—I should not know them again to swear to them, it was very dark—I can swear it was not the prisoner—the person was taller than the prisoner—the man moved from the stile when I came up, and I passed between the two—I did not get over the stile—I never saw Claridge till after this—as far as I cam judge, the man was about the size of Claridge—he was dressed in a lightish coloured frock, or flannel waistcoat—I could not tell which, but it was a light dress—my house is about a hundred yards from the well in which Mrs. Haggerstone was found—shortly after I got home, I heard two persons walking through the gate into the little field, and talking together very gently—that little field leads into the Winding-shot field—it appeared to be a man and woman talking—I went to bed a few minutes after—my lodger was afterwards called up, when Mrs. Haggerstone was found in the well.

WILLIAM CLARIDGE . I am a labourer. On the 16th of April I was at work on the rail-road at Merton, and was at the White Hart at Merton—I suppose I was there four hours—I saw Mrs. Haggerstone there for about an hour and a half—I was there before she came in—I believe I went out before her—I should think that must have been half-past eleven o'clock,

or from that to a quarter to twelve o'clock—she came out directly after me, and we went up the road together for about a quarter of a mile, up to Mr. Saunders's—Mr. and Mrs. Hedges walked up with us at the same time—Mrs. Hedges was there—they talked to us—Mrs. Hedges talked to us—the Hedges were a little before me when they got to the beer-shop—Mrs. Haggerstone and I did not walk quite so fast—Mr. and Mrs. Hedges went into the beer-shop, and I and Mrs. Haggerstone stopped outside—she was waiting in them—we waited there a quarter of an hour altogether, and then the prisoner came up—he said to his wife, "D—n you, madam, I have been looking for you some time"—then he up with his right fist, and took her on the left side of her face, with his doubled fist, and said, "D—n you, madam, if you don't go your ways home I will murder you"—after that she bid me good night, and they went off quarrelling together, and I saw no more a them that night—I should think this must have been about half-past twelve o'clock, or more than that—a quarter to one—they went up the lane that leads to the Winding-shop field, and to their but, and I went to the baker's opposite Saunders's—I lodge at Saunders's—I was not at the baker's two minutes, I should think, for when I got there they were shut up—I never went over to my lodging in Saunders's—the Hedges were just gone out—they came out while I was at the baker's—I did not are them come out—I never saw them after went in—while Mrs. Haggerstone and I were waiting for them, we stood in the same place—I was called up on Sunday morning by the constable and overseer, and was taken into custody, but not when they first came for me—I went to work on Sunday morning after they called me up—they told me about Mrs. Haggerstone being found in the well—I went to work after that—I was taken into custody about nine o'clock that morning—Haggerstone and I were at the White Hart together about twelve o'clock in custody, on the Sunday, in the parlour of the White Hart—and we were there on the Monday—he then told me not to say any thing of what happened on the Saturday between him and his wife—I was then under charge myself—that was before I went before the Coroner—the Coroner came on Tuesday, and I made my first statement on the Thursday following—I was discharged as the Monday night after I made my second statement—I was kept in custody from Sunday, the 17th till the Monday in the following week—I was not discharged till after I had made my second statement.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. When you made second statement on the Monday, did you give the same account as you had given on the Thursday? A. No, I did not—I did not say any thing about the prisoner's striking his wife, till the Monday night, when I told the constable about it—I did not tell the Coroner of it till Monday—I was in custody on this very charge—the prisoner wished me not to do it.
COURT. Q. You, who were under examination, chose to obey him, though you had seen all this cruelty to his wife? A. Yes.
MR. DOANE? Q. Were you on oath? A. No: the reason I kept it back was because the prisoner told me to—that was my reason.
COURT. Q. Why, at the time you had no doubt in your own mind that he had done this—at the time you kept it back? A. I could not tell—I did not see it myself—I could not say he did it.

MR. DOANE. Q. Had you heard, that shortly after the prisoner treated her as you describe, that she was found in the well? A. I heard of it next day, within an hour or two after she was found—they came to me about half-past five o'clock in the morning—I should expect that the prisoner

had done it, myself—it was a violent blow that he gave her—I did not offer to protect her—she tried to defend herself as well as he could—she pushed up against him—she staggered up against him—she went nearer to him after he struck her—that is what I saw—I did not call out for Hedges to come—I did not go to Saunders and ask him to protect the woman—I do not know Mr. Hone—I have seen him since this, but I did not know him—I am a stranger about there.

Q. As you believed he was the man who did this wicked deed, and did not disclose it because he desired you not, why do it on Monday? A. I thought it was right to speak what I knew—I did not know the surgeon had been examined when I made my statement—I knew a doctor had been called in—I cannot say what day he went before the Coroner—Monday was the last day of the Inquest—I was in a room by myself during all the proceedings on Monday—Mrs. Haggerstone bid me "Good night," after the till-treatment, as if nothing had happened.

Q. Now, did you not expect, by making the declaration you did, against the prisoner, on Monday, that you might save yourself by it? A. No; I did not—I knew myself innocent of it—I did not make the statement on Thursday because he wanted me no to do it.

COURT. Q. Are you a married man? A. Yes; I lived at Saunders's beer-shop, at this time—I live at Paddington when I am at home—I did not call for assistance when the outrage was committed on the woman—she never called out at all—I do not know whether I am taller than the prisoner—I did not consider I had any business between man and wife—the woman never called out, and I did not interfere—I never said a word to the Coroner, about his saying, "D—n you, if you don't go your ways, I will murder you"—I cannot tell whether I am taller and stouter than the prisoner, or not—he was in front of the woman when he gave her the blow.

WILLIAM DEKINS . I was neat Mr. Wyatt's lane on the Saturday night, on which Mrs. Haggerstone was found in the well, about half-past twelve o'clock—Wyatt's lane is not exactly in a direction between Saunders' beer-shop and Haggerstone's—it is close at the side—it lies to the right in going from Saunder's to Winding-shot-field—it is close by the field—I heard two persons talking, over in the field as I came round by Mr. Wyatt's—I heard two voices, whether male or female, I cannot tell—one of them either said, "D—n my eyes I have been to the Crown," or "I will go to the Crown"—I cannot tell which—the well is about 100 yards from where I heard the voices—they were talking loud—they appeared to me to be fall
ing out—I heard nothing more in the lane; but after I went home I heard a dreadful scream once.

SARAH STEEL . On the 16th of April I lived in Payne's-lane, at Morton, in a cottage about twenty or thirty yards from the well, and about 100 or 200 yards from the Winding-Shot-field—I think it might be more—I went to bed about half-past nine o'clock—my husband came to bed about half-past ten o'clock—after being in bed some time, I was awoke by my child—I awoke my husband, to get out of bed to get a napkin for my child, and heard a noise—it appeared like quarreling—I heard a woman's voice—my little boy cried, and I could hear no others—I heard nothing besides voices, as my little boy drowned the noise by crying—I asked my husband to go to the door—we slept on the ground-floor—he went to the door and came back to me—in consequence of what he said, I went to the door, and heard a woman's voice scream twice—it appeared to come from

the well—I heard a woman say, "Oh, my dear children! oh my dear baby; "—it was then turned of one o'clock—I know that, because my check was at my bed-room door, and I had a light in my house—I cannot say how long after one o'clock it was, but my clock was turned the half hour, and it was half an hour too fast—I immediately went to the well—by the time I had got there the noise from the woman had ceased—I say for taken out of the well, at my own door—I did not stop at the well—it was some time before the body was got out—I knew Mrs. Haggerstone when she was alive—I cannot say whether it was her body, for I did not know it—she knew my cottage, and where the well was, because I have talked to her at my stile, within a fortnight of her death.

GEORGE GREEN . I assisted in taking the body of Mrs. Haggerstone out of the well, and took it down to the White Hart. I afterwards were so Haggerstone's—I did not see him—I heard his voice—I knew him before—when we told him his wife was very poorly down at the White Hart, he said he would not come—we then told him his wife was deadhe said he could not help it, he would not come until the morning, to tell Mr. Parsons—Parsons is the landlord of the White Hart—Steel was with me—it was a very dark night—I did not go to the house again.

WILLIAM CLEAVES . I found a bonnet and a bit of an old handkerchief, in a ditch about seven yards behind the back of the well, on Sunday morning, after Mrs. Haggerstone's death, there was only one string to the bonnet—I found the other string on the Monday morning in the the Short-three-acre field—the well is forty-nine rods and a half from the Short-three-acre field—it is at the top of the Winding-shot field—I gave the bonnet and string to Hart the constable.

JOSEPH JOHNSON . On the Monday after Mrs. Haggerstone was found in the well, I found a cap near the top of Winding-shot field, on the Wyatts side—I found a stick about a foot and a half from the laid up on the bank—there was a place on the bank where somebody had been sitting down—it did not appear as if more than one person had been sitting there.
Cross-examined. Q. Was it a sloping bank? A. Yes—it appeared as if somebody had been sitting down—not lying down, the grass was just pressed down—I observed no footmarks there.

HENRY HART . I am a constable. I went to Claridge on the Sunday morning—and to the prisoner's house with Mrs. Searl—we arrived the about half-past four or five o'clock—we called the prisoner up from the outside of the house—he came to the door almost directly I called himhe had got his trowsers on—I asked him why he did not come when the people called him, and told him his wife was dead—he said he could not tall for any reason, or why was the reason—he turned towards Hedges' bed, which is in the same room, and said, "D—my eyes, this is all through that Claridge"—Hedges said to him, "You have brought yourself to a b—y fine mean at last"—the prisoner came away from the cottage with me, without making any reply—I took him immediately to the well where his wife's body had been found—it was then at the White Hart—I pointed out the well to him and said, "Haggerstone this is where your wife was found"—he looked over into the well, and said, "Yes, there is some of the bread swimming now"—I had not mentioned to him that she had had any bread—I afterwards took him to the White Hart, and shewed him the body, and he said, "Oh, poor deer creature"—I let him go at large after that—I took him

again about one o'clock the same day, and he was let go again on the Thursday following—that was after Claridge was examined—I also had Claridge in custody—he made a declaration to me in the presence of Ayton and Parsons on the second Sunday night—at the time he was in custody and Parsons on the second Sunday night—at that time he was in the Sunday—I cannot exactly say the time—it was several hours after I had told Claridge of the body being found in the well.

Cross-examined. Q. Claridge was never let out of custody from the day he was taken till the Monday week following? A. No—the prisoner was not taken again till after the second declaration made the Claridge.

COURT. Q. The deceased washed for Claridge—did not Claridge say to you, that same Sunday night, that he should not know Mrs. Haggerstone if he saw her? A. I have heard him say so—he said he did not believe he should know her—that he should not have known her before, if he had not seen her that night—it was in consequence of what Claridge mentioned to my brother constable that I took the prisoner again—I produces the stick, handkerchief, and cap.

JAMES FILMORE . I live at Merton. I have known the prisoner ever since he has been there—I saw him on Sunday morning, about nine o'clock, after his wife's death, at the Nelson's Arms, at Merton—we went up the London-road together, and as we went along he stopped to tell the people about his wife—we went on further, and came to a woman named wife—she said, "David, when you lived with me you were always a rascal to her, and so you have still remained"—he made no answer—I went into the Bells with him—there were several people in the tap-room, and he said, "It was a lucky job I happened to meet this chap (meaning me), or else my name would have been B1—y Walker, and my family at Merton should never have seen me any more"—when we left the Bells was went over Phipps-briedge—before we came to the bridge he attempted to drown himself, and I prevented him—the water was about ten feet deep there—he afterwards said to me, "Jem, I know the man that has murdered my wife, and if it costs me my life I will hang him"—nothing more passed.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he mention the person's name? A. Yes; Claridge—when he said it was lucky he had met with me I understood him to allude to self destruction.
WILLIAM SAUNDERS . I keep a beer-shop at Merton. Clardige lodges at my house—I do not know who washed for him.

WILLIAM CLABIDGE (re-examined.) The deceased washed for me one week—I gave the linen to the husband—I had not seen her when she began to wash for me—I knew her afterwards—she brought the linen home to the White Hart, and I saw her then for the first time.

ROBERT SAMUEL SIMMS . I am a surgeon living at Merton. I was called on to examine the body of Mrs. Haggerstone on Sunday morning, the 17th of April, about half-past two o'clock at the White Hart—at that time I only made an external examination—it appeared that she had been dead above an hour—there was the appearance of a blow on the right side of her face, and a great deal of swelling—I did not consider it possible at that time to ascertain how those appearance had been produced—when the swelling had subsided there appeared indentations of knuckles—it was by candle-lights that I first saw the body, which is the reason I could not decide then—I thought all the external appearance of the body were those I should have expected to have found in a person who had been drowned—I observed

scratches about the legs and thighs, both interior and posterior—they appeared to have been made by brambles and thorn s—they were scratches of that description—I afterwards made a more minute examination and opened the body by the Coroner's directions on Wednesday—the immediate cause of death was in my opinion from suffocation by drowning—there was no appearance whatever of external violence on the head—on each outer side of the wrist there was the appearance of blows, I think those blows were produced before death, I think they could not be caused by falling down the well—it was a very deep well—I should think twelve feet deep and three feet wide—there was some bar in the well against which she must have rested at first—I think it very likely she might he bruised by going against the sides of the well—there were many appearances of blows on the back—I think they might be cause by falling down the well against the bar—I am informed the well was formerly a pump and some bars remain across the well against which she must have rested—there were a few scratches on her arms—I think the scratches in the interior of the thighs were produced by bram
bles, and I should say prior to death—I examined the organs of generation at the post mortem examination on Wednesday—there appeared to have been recent excitement of those parts but nothing conclusive—I think there was no appearance of force on those parts, nor any laceration, nothing of the kind—I should think it most difficult to ascertain that point, and it was the opinion of three surgeons with me—the excitement I allude to might have been produced in other ways also—there was the appearance of a blow below the groin near the parts of generation—it appeared to me to have been produced in the same way as the below on the face, with the knuckles, although there was not indentation, there was the same lividness parts of it—we divided the integument of the brain—there appeared nine or ten portions of extravagated blood as if that had been produced by blows—the immediate cause of death was suffocation from drowning—I have not the least hesitation about it—the blow on the head might have produced very serious symptoms had she not been put into the well.

Cross-examined. Q. Were there any blows on the right side of the face? A. Yes—I did not observe any on the left—I certainly should have observed it if there had been—the blow near the parts of generation could not have been produced by a man's knee—it was narrow mark—the knuckles of a hand might have done it—I think constant and violent pressure of three knuckles of the hand might have produced similar up, pearances—there was some glutinous fluid which might have been—a disease, or it might have been produced in some other way—I have gone over the field in all parts of it—there are many hedges and ditches, containing brambles and fences.

JOSEPH JOHNSON
re-examined. There are not many brambles about where I found the stick—there are a few—enough to scratch—it is pretty nearly a quarter of a mile, I should think, from Saunders's beer-shop.

Prisoner's Defence. I came from the Crown, tipsy, that night, at a little after eight o'clock, and left my wife by the double gates at Merton, with the intention of going to her sister's, Mrs. Wright—I never saw her any more till she was a corpse—I bid two persons "Good night" in going home—one of them is a constable of the parish, named Brockwell—I went home to bed, and never heard of it till the alarm was given.
WILLIAM BROCKWELL . I am headborough of Merton, and live just by the church. On the Saturday evening in question I was in bed, and had
been asleep—it was near eleven o'clock I think—I heard the prisoner cry out to me, "Good night"—I knew him before.
MR. CHAMBERS. Q. How far is your house from Saunders's beer-shop? A. Not a quarter of a mile, and about 150 yards from the Wioding-shot field.
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1361.
CHARLES GRAY was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of April, 7 sacks, value 5s., the goods of
James Clark and another.

MR. BODKIN conducted the Prosecution. JAMES CLARK. I have a granary, at Lee's wharf, in Upper Ground-street. I have a partner—on the 23rd of April the prisoner came to our granary, and ordered 3-qrs. of oats, a sack of beans, a saok of split beans, and a quarter of bran, to be sent to his stable in Hatfield-street—he gave me to understand he had but one saddle-horse there, as he did not like to put his horse to a livery-stable—that his bailiff was coming from his estate at St. Albans, where he came from, once a week, to bring new milk and cream to his town house—I told him it was not our custom to leave sacks with any corn we sent out—he said they should he shot at the place and the sacks returned, and he might send the money back by the man, if not, he would send it in the morning—I gave a delivery ticket for the corn, and sent it by Corderoy, which the prisoner signed and returned—I have never been paid for my corn, nor seen the prisoner since, till I found him at the office, surrrounded by fifty or sixty creditors.

Prisoner. Q. How often have I bought corn of you before? A. Only once—you did not pay me for two quantities of corn—you paid one bill—you never told me you should pay for one quantity under the other, or that you wanted to borrow the sacks for a few days, as you had not a place to about the corn in.

FRANCIS CORDEROY . I am carter to Mr. Clark and his partner. I went with the corn, beans and bran to Hatfield-street, and saw the prisoner there—I asked him if he would let me have the sacks—he said I might shoot two and take them back, and leave seven, and he would send them back next morning by one of his men—I had had directions at the wharf about the sacks before I went there—I tole the prisoner I was not to leave them—he said I must, and he would return the seven next morning—I was induced, in consequence of that, to leave them—they did not came next morning, and I went after them, but found the stable shut up—I inquired for the prisoner, but could find him no where—nobody could give me any account of him, till I found him at Mary-le-bone office on other charges.
Prisoner. Q. Did I not once before have corn, and you leave the sacks? A. I was never at your place before in my life.

JOHN DEDMAN . I am a police-inspector. I saw the prisoner after he was apprehended—he said he never had stable in Hatfield-street in his life—I found the delivery ticket for the corn among his papers.

FRANCIS CORDEROY
re-examined. This is the paper the prisoner signed when I left the sacks.

Prisoner's Defence. I borrowed the stables in Hatfield-street of a man who kept two cab horses there—I bought the things of the prosecutor—I had previously paid him two accounts, and on both occasions the sacks were left to oblige me—I had no corn bin at the time—I was

then living in Duke-street, Stamford-street, with Mr. Jennings, and had two horses standing there—one was any own, and the other I had to tell for a person—I expected to have some more-horses, instead of which the man absconded with his cab and horses, and left me in the stable—in consequence of which I gave the sacks and oats into the care of a man named Stone, who stands in Farringdon-street, and who keeps a cab, and is related to Mr. Benson—I desired him to take the sacks back again to Mr. Clark's—till I found this prosecution against me, I saw not in the least aware but the sacks were returned—I hope and trust you will feel I should not endeavour to embezzle property to the amount of 5s. as to the corn, my intention was to pay for it, but, unfortunately, ever since I have become a bankrupt, all my property came into the hands of creditors, which has reallzed above 10s. in the pound—I know this is a vindictions prosecution against me, from a circumstance I am not at liberty to state to you—Clark and Co. might have proved their debt under the estate then is well known I took of Lord Radnor—I never represented I had an estate at St. Alban's—Benson refuses to come here, and I have no mean of subpcening him.

GUILTY . Aged 52.—
Transported for Seven Years.
Second Jury, before Mr. Justice Park.

1362.
EDWARD NUNN and
DAVID NUNN was indicted
for a robbery on
Henry Harding, on the 10th of May, putting him in fear, and taking from his person, and against his will, 1 hat, value 5s.; and 1 handkerchief, value 6d.; his goods.

HENRY HARDING . I am a hair-dresser, and live in Carlisle-place Lambeth. On Monday night, the 10th of May, I had been cut to spead the evening at the King's Arms, in Horsemonger-lane—I was sober—I had been there about three hours—I was walking home with John Chopman, between twelve and one o'clock, at the side of the pin manufacturers, leading to the Borough-rond—I was suddenly knocked down by one of the prisoners—I had not observed any body before they struck me on my head—it was done with the fist, I suppose—I fell on the ground, and grazed my face, and my friend left me—before I got up my hat fell off, and when I re
covered myself, I found Edward Nunn upon me—I was a little stunned—after he left me, I saw him pick my hat up and run away with it—there was a handkerchief in it—I only saw on person there at that time, but after I got up the other prisoner came up, and we had a scuffle together—I should thing that was not a minute after the other prisoner was gone—we both fell, and I called "Murder" and "Police"—Cowline, the policeman, then came up—my finger and thumb were hart a good deal—the con
stable took hold of us both, and parted us—my hat was brought back in three or four minutes by another policeman—the handkerchief was not it it—I did not see the person who knocked me down, but I should know him again if I were to see him—I did not see the man who gave me the first blow, but Edward is the man who lay on me—I saw my handkerchief at Union-hall.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Do you mean to say this young man gave you a blow without any provocation of any kind from you? A. Yes: we were not both struggling which should keep the wall—I and my friend were walking in the road—I never knew the prisoners before—they made no attempt to take any money from me—I had only six pennyworth of halfpence about me—it was from the blow that my hat fell

off—they did not attempt to take it off—we had about three pots of ale between three of us at the King's Arms—I do not think there was more—Chapman paid for it—I drank nothing but ale—no spirits—none was drank in the company.

JOHN CHAPMAN . I was with the prosecutor at the King's Arms—we had been there three hours and a half or four hours—we had ale to drink—I do not think we had any thing else—I paid half-a-crown for the drink—as we proceeded along a street leading into the Borough-road, we were not by two persons—they were together—I could see there were some persons in the street, but not so as distinguish them—they came up towards us, and both attacked my friend—I ran away, and cannot tell what happened afterwards—I did not see my friend on the ground—they were both strug
gling together when I quitted the spot—they had not got him on the ground when I left—I passed on when they attacked me—it was in the horse way I rather think; it was by the side of the pin manufactory—it was not on the flag-stones—I cannot say what they were scuffling about when I ran off—I cannot say whether anything was said when they came up—I did not call "Murder"—it was put down as such before the Magistrate, but I did not assert it—this is my signature—I do not think it was read over to me—I was sworn.

Q. You were sworn to tell the truth, and said, "I saw the prisoners walk-up to us, and immediately the prosecutor was on the ground—I ran off directly, and called out "Murder, and went home:" now, did you me him on the ground? A. No, I cannot say I did.

Cross-examined. Q. Perhaps you forgot what you swore before she Magistrate? A. There might be a little error regarding what I might say before the Magistrate—my evidence was taken down—I cannot say it was send over—it was not, to the best of my belief—I was asked to sign it, and did—I had been taking more ale that night than I usually did—it might have got into my head—I cannot remember a word passing between the parties when they began the scuffle—I was frightened, I cannot say that I called out "Murder"—I do not think Harding paid any thing that night for drink—another person was with us—he paid about 1s. perhaps—I cannot say whether it was 1s.—6d., or 18d.—I think the ale was 9d.—I cannot say whether it skittle-ground—I do not think we drank more than four quarts—there was smoking—I did not stop long enough to ascertain whether one of the prisoners was tipsy.

JOHN RICHARD COWLING . I am a policeman. I was in the Borough-road on the night in question, and heard a cry of "Murder" for Harding—I heard the cry of "Murder" from more than one person, I think—I went up, and found the prosecutor and David Nunn strnggling on the ground—I did not see the other—I passed a third person just before I got there, but whether it was the other prisoner or the last witness I cannot say—I parted them—the prosecutor said he had lost his hat—John Butt, a policeman, came up with it immediately—the prosecutor claimed it—there was no handkerchief in it—neither the prisoner David nor the prosecutor were drunk—the other prisoner was brought back in custody, with the hat—It think he had been drinking a little, but he was not drunk.

Cross-examined. Q. Did any thing happen to the prosecutor at the station-house? A. Not that I know of—not to my knowledge—he dirtied himself either before he got to the station-house, or while he was there, or while he was being attacked—he smelt very bad—I do not know that I
ever saw the prisoners before—a handkerchief was found on Edward Nunn I believe, but I was not present.

JOHN BUTT . I am a policeman. On the night in question I saw the prisoner, Edward Nunn, in Marshall-street, Borough-road, between twelve and one o'clock, running—he had a hat in his hand—he was coming from the prosecutor—I stopped him, and took him back to where the prosecutor and Cowline were—I stopped him about 150 yards from where they went—I am certain this is the hat I took from him.

WILLIAM REED . I am a policeman, I heard a cry of "Murder," and went up to the place—I saw Cowling and David Nunn there, and afterwards saw Edward brought back—I searched him at the station-house, and found the handkerchief in his pocket—David Nunn's waistcoat, was torn—he said, in the prosecutor's hearing, that he had hit them, and had torn his waistcoat, and that he had struck him first—the prosecutor was not at all tipay.

Edward Nunn's Defence. I called on my brother, at a general meeting that was held of a union to keep up the price of the work—I was drunk, and my brother went to see me home from the Lion, which is not more than eight minutes walk from the house—we were arm, and met the prosecutor on the pavement, by the wall—he requested the wall, and I, being drunk would not give it up—he struck me on the head—I fell, which perhaps, I might not have done, if I had been sober—after that I got up, and hit him again—I believed him to be very drunk, and he fell—but before that, I have my brother call out to chapman to take his friend away—Chapman me after my brother—after that, I picked up the hat, and the handkerchief some little way further on, with the intent to give it to the owner, let it be who it would—I could not tell whether it was my brother's, the prosecutor's, or the witness's—I had no intention of taking it away—I met that policeman, and said, "Here is a hat belonging to some body," and I went back with him without being asked—I gave him the hat.

David Nunn's Defence. I was at Mr. Hicks's about half-past eleven o'clock, on Monday evening—my brother called for me—I thought he was tipay, and went to see him home—we met the prosecutor and his witness arm in arm—they would take the wall, and my brother would not let them—he struck my brother in the eye—and he fell—my brother struck him again.

JOHN BUTT
re-examined. I asked the prisoner Edward to let me look at the hat, and he gave it to me.

ALEXANDER HICKS . My father keeps the Red Lion public-house is Pearl-row, Blackfriar's-road—I saw both the prisoners there, on Monday night last—David was there all the evening—Edward came in about twenty minutes after eleven o'clock—I saw them leave the house, and wished them "Good night"—Edward was tipsy—they have both borne honest characters.
Third Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1363.
THOMAS HILL was indicted
for feloniously stealing, on the 18th of September, 1 looking glass, value 10s.; 8 chairs, value 10s.; 2 pieces of floor-cloth, value 5s.; 2 carpets, value 5l.; 1 pair of steps, value 1s.; 1 bench, value 1s.; 1 coal-hod, value 1s.; 2 cornices, value 1s.; 4 curtains, value 10s.; 1 scraper, value 1s.; 1 tin can, value 1d.; 1 warming-span, value 2s.; 1 steak-coaster, value 6d.; 1 footman, value 1s.; 1 candle-box, value 6d.; 20 pieces of earthenware, value 1s.; and 1 door lock, value 1s.; the goods of
William Surman Chambers, in his dwelling-house.—2nd COUNT, stating them to be the goods of
William, by Divine providence, Primate of all England and Metropolitan—3rd COUNTS, of
Richard Chambers Herbert .

THOMAS WHITEHEAD . I am a policeman. I went to the prisoner's house, on Monday, the 2nd of May, between two and three o'clock, at the request of Mr. Bedford—it is No.1, Mason-street, Lambeth—I did not take him into custody, at that time—Mr. Bedford and Mr. Barton went to get the magistrate's advice, and on their return, they gave the prisoner into custody, and about nine o'clock, I found this carpet in an upper room.

WILLIAM CHAMBERS BARTON . I am the natural son of the late Mr. William Surman Chambers—I was in the habit of visiting him—I lived in one of his house—he had ten houses in Whitehorse-street, Lambeth—he lived at No. 20—I was acquainted with his articles of furniture—I was at the house two or three times every day, for about twelve or eighteen months, till he went into the country, which was in July, 1834, and he died on the 17th of September following—this carpet was down in his frosst room tip-stairs, which was the room he occupied—about a month before he left, he directed me to take this carpet up, beat it, and fold it up, and put it is the black-room, on the same floor, and I did so before he left—the prisoner lodged in the lower part of the house, and paid the rent to my father—my father generally slept in the front room, and made use of the back-room as a sitting-room—he had no servant—the prisoner occupied two rooms on the ground-floor, and the kitchen—I saw him on the 6th of October following—I went into the back-room, and saw this curpet is the same place as I had placed it in before my father went into the country—I picked the key up in the front room, and the prisoner went in and unlocked the door, and I then saw the carpet there—on the 2nd of May, last, I went with Mr. Bedford to the prisoner's house, in Mason-street, and saw the carpet in an empty top room, wrapped up—we asked the prisoner to allow us permission to see what furniture he had, as we believed he had some belonging to the late Mr. Chambers—he said he had not any belonging to him—I afterwards found the carpet, which I am positive was my father's property.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had you lived with your father? A. I lived in a house belonging to him—I never slept in my father's house—I did not visit him for about a fortnight before he left home—before that I was there two or three times a day—I had a quarrel with him about a fortnight before his death—I got into the police and left, by disobeying the orders of my superior officer—I was not discharged—I discharged myself—I would not swear that—I was removed—Mr. and Mrs. Hill were used to my father during his illness, as far as friendship went—Mrs. Hill used to go up and attend to him at times, but I used to nurse him myself.

Q. During the last fortnight you could not, for you were not allowed to see him? A. I saw him the day he went into the country—I came to the house several times, and saw him, but was not friends with him—I do not know that Mrs. Hill was reproved for letting me in by stealth—I never heard the prisoner say that my father had made them a present of the things of their kindness to him—I never heard my father say so—I have heard the prisoner say that my father gave him the things, and he claimed there as his own.
re-examined. Q. When did you first hear the prisoner say so? A. After my father's death—there was nobody with me then—the prisoner gave

me a silver snuff-box and spoons, and said, "These belonged to your father and I give them to you"—I said, "Very well, I will keep them for his sake," and I gave them to the administrator, Mr. Herbert—the prisoner, gave them to me at his house, No.20, White Horse-street—he said he should keep the other things that he had in his possession, and nobody should taken them—he said he considered that my father had given them to him in his waiting on my father, and kindness to him about the fortnight before I fell out with him—he did not give me any more things—the looking-glass, mahogany chairs, and window-curtains, were pun, under she prisoner care—the oil-cloth was put down in the passage in my father's dwelling house.
COURT. Q. Was he left in charge of the things when your father went out of town? A. All the things except the carpet, which was locked up in my father's room.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Were you present when your father delivered then things into his care? A. No.

HENRY BEDFORD . I am solicitor to Mr. Herbert. He has taken out an administration to the effects of the deceased—here are the letters of administration with the will annexed, it is dated, 1827—there in no bequest to the prisoner in the will—I went with Mr. Herbert to the deceased house, in October, 1834—we were shown two rooms belonging to the de
ceased by Mrs. Hill—I do not think the prisoner was present—the rooms were both locked—the keys could not be found—it was supposed that the deceased had them with him—but we at last found a key which would open the front room, and in that room we found the will, and took an in
ventory of the things—we left the back room locked as it was—on the 9th of October we went again, the prisoner and his wife were there then—I said he had not got any key, that the deceased had got it with him, as he supposed, and we burst the door of the back room open—the key we got on the 6th was either found about the house, or Mr. Herbert had it with him, having found it in the deceased's pocket—the rooms were locked up—the prisoner did not pretend to have the control of the things at all—the carpet was not there on the 9th of October—I never saw it till the 2nd of May this year.
First Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1364.
JOHN PRICE was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of April, 1 half-crown, 2 shillings, and 1 sixpence, the monies of
William Lucey, from his person.

WILLIAM LUCEY . I am a lighterman, and live in East-lane. On the 18th of April, I was in the pit at Astley's theatre—the prisoner stood up behind me—I was standing on the sear, and he on the ground—I felt his right-hand, rifling my left pocket—he had not spoken to me before—I left both his hands at my left pocket—I had about 5l. 8s. in silver in it—I had counted it in the morning—I had spent some after, but I deducted that—I was quite sober—the prisoner made two or three attempts at my pocket, and the money dropped from his hand, which I felt fall in my pocket—I imagine he had a five-shilling-piece in his hand, as I heard it drop in my pocket—I at last lost about 5s.—after the fourth attempt I put my right hand to my pocket, and when he found I was suspicious of him, he put his hand over my shoulder, and spoke about the performance—I then charged him with it, and he was taken—there was some property
found on him, but I cannot say whether it was mine—he might have dropped it—when I recounted my money, I missed four or five shillings.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE Q. Can you tell what coins that was la? A. I cannot—it was in silver—there was a great crowd in front of me in the theatre.

MARK WILLIAM GREEN (police-constable L 28.) the prosecutor charged the prisoner with putting his hand into his pocket, but not with stealing any thing—I found nine sovereigns, one half-crown, and 6d., on the prisoner.

1365.
JOHN PRICE was again indicted
for a misdemeanor.
Second Jury before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1366.
HENRY GREENFIELD was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of May, 1 coat, value 1s.; 1 pair of trowsers, value 7s.; and 2 pencil-cases, value 3s.; the goods of
George Hurst; to which he pleaded.

GUILTY .—
Confined Two Days.
(William Culverhouse, of Osborn-street, Whitechapel, gave the prisoner's good character, and promised to send him home to his friends at Boulogne.)

1367.
JOHN WILLIAMS was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of April, 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
John Bond Ratcliffe, from his person.

JOHN BOND RATCLIFFE . I was going through Union-street, South-wark, on the 20th of April, about half-past four o'clock, and stopped to allow some carriages to pass—I felt my handkerchief drawn from me—I turned and saw the prisoner crossing the road with it under his arm—I took it from him and gave him into custody.
JOHN FEAR (police-constable M 42.) I was called and received the prisoner and the handkerchief.
Prisoner. There were a mob—a young man and woman were passing—I saw this handkerchief drop—I picked it up, and was putting it into my pocket, and the prosecutor seized me.
JOHN BOND RATCLIFFE . There was no one nearer me than him—I know it was him took it from me, and he owned to it afterwards.

GUILTY .* Aged 25.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1368.
WILLIAM RATCLIFFE was indicted
for stealing, on the 29th of April, 1 sovereign, the monies of
Peter Annand, his master.

PETER ANNAND . I live at Bridge-road, Lambeth, and am a confectioner. The prisoner was in my employ for about ten days—I saw this sovereign safe in the till about nine o'clock at night on the 29th of April, and missed it before ten o'clock, I immediately made inquiries of the prisoner—he denied having it—when he had got his great coat on, and was going away, I called him back—he waited in my parlour till I fetched a constable—he still denied having it, but the constable found it in his waistcoat pocket—he then said he picked it up from under the counter.

Prisoner. I found it under the counter—I did not know whose it was—my master did not ask me if I had got it till the policeman came. Witness. I did—he said he had not got it, that he had seen it in the till, but he did not know where it was.

THOMAS ALESBURY (police-constable L 136.) I was called in, and the prosecutor said to him, "Have you got the sovereign?"—the prisoner said no, he had not—I found it in his waistcoat pocket, among some halfpence—he then said he had picked it up on the floor, and asked forgiveness of his master.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 12.—
Whipped and discharged.
Sixth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1369.
ISAAC ALTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of April 4 hams, value 2l. 6s., the goods of
John Humphery, being on a wharf ad
jacent to a certain navigable river.
JAMES HUTCHINGS . I am private watchman to Mr. Hunpherys: his name is John. I do not exactly know whether there is an a to his some or not to it.

EDWARD THOROGOOD . I do not know Hutchings—I do not know what ward he is watchman to—I know a gentleman of the name of John Has
phery—he is proprietor of Haye's Wharf, Tooley-street—I mean the Alderman—his wagons are over London-bridge continually.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Do not wagoners and carters often go on a wharf which they do not belong to? A. I only know the what belongs to him by taking letters directed to him, to the hotel at the end of our bridge—I do not know what connexion the hotel has with the wharf.

JAMES HUTCHINGS
re-examined. My master is Mr. Alderman Humphery, and he owns Haye's wharf. On Sunday morning, about quarter past four o'clock, I came on shore from the tier of vessels on the wharf—my business in on board ship and on shore—I came from The Lord Glenlyon—I found the prisoner concealed between some hogsheads of hams—which were lying on the cast side of Haye's Wharf—he was lying on his belly, and three hams were lying on his feet, between two and three yards from a hogshead which was broken open—he pretended to be intoxicated, but was not—I secured him of stealing these hams—he told me he only meant to take one—I said I should lock him up, and asked him what hogshead was broken open, and where the hams came from—he went and shewed me the hogshead that was broken open, and told me the hams came out of that—the hogshead was lying with the heads pressed out, and the hams strewed about—there ought to have been forty-eight hams in the hogshead, and there were forty-three—those at his feet seemed to correspond with those in the hogshead.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You say he was not drunk? A. I will swear it—he had not the opportunity to go off with them, because I came upon him so quickly—I had been there about two hours before—he could not have been there an hour and a half, because the vessel he was on board, was not in berth till twenty or thirty minutes before I found him—I put the vessel in myself, so that there was not time to go and break open the hogshead and take the hams on board a ship—I know two hams were found on board, he had not time to take the five hams away—he had not time to take a third ham on board—his ship laid about ten yards from the place—he could not have taken five hams and put them on board the vessel—he pretended to have been asleep—I came on him too quickly for him to walk off to the vessel—he was lying on his belly between the hogsheads, and the hams lay on the back part of his legs—he could have placed them there very easily—it would be the readiest way to get them out from between the hogsheads—there was a visitor on board the ship, named West—the captain and mate were down aft, West was walking

the deck and took him into custody—I told him he might come and clear himself—he had no business to be there as he did not belong to the ship—he came to visit the prisoner on the might before—I knew the berth in which West slept—I found one ham in his berth and Alton's—West has got no berth on board the ship—the captain told me he was a visitor—I found a ham underneath the prisoner's bed—it was not a berth—it was a lumber
place—the captain and the mate told me it was the prisoner's berth.
