COURT. Q. You found three hams on his legs, and he said he meant only to steal one? A. He did, and he showed me the cask from whence he took them—the hams were wanted to go away, and four were returned which are not here.

GEORGE TAYLOR . I was called—I had just done swinging the vessels—the witness pointed out the man lying on his belly, with three hams on his legs—Hutchings called him out, and asked what he was going to do—he said he intended to take one ham, if he had not come so quick upon him—Hutchings asked him where he got the hams from—he said they came out of the hogshead—Hutchings said, "Show me the hogshead they came out of"—he got in between the hogsheads, and showed him—he was quite sober, but tried to appear drunk.

Cross-examined. Q. How could a man, lying on his belly, put three hams on his legs, when he had not room to move himself? A. He could put them over his shoulder, on his legs—his head might be a yard and a half from the hogshead which was lying on its bilge—the hams were all shot out—some of them were lying close to his hand—he could not get out say other way than by putting them on his legs—he had not room to turn himself—he was obliged to back himself out astern.
WILLIAM LEGG . I am warehouseman to Mr. Humphery. I saw these hogshead safe on Saturday night, between nine and ten o'clock.
Cross-examined. Q. Whose property were these while they were an Mr. Humphery's wharf? A. They belonged to him—I call him Alderson John Humphery.
Prisoner. I was drunk between twelve and one o'clock, and do not know how I came there.
(Robert Johnson, the prisoner's brother-in-law, gave him a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Four Months.
Fifth Jury before Mr. Recorder.

1370.
CHARLES CAULFIELD was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of April, 1 shilling and 1 sixpence, the monies of
John Ruck and another, his masters.
MR. CHAMBERS declined offering any evidence.

1371.
CHARLES CAULFIELD and
GEORGE ASH were indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of April, 2 shillings and 1 sixpence, the monies of
JOHN RUCK and another, the masters of the said Charles Caulfield.
MR. CHAMBERS conducted the Prosecution.

JOHN RUCK . I live in High-street, Borough, and am a cheesemonger, in partnership with my brother. About seven weeks previous to this discovery, the prisoner Caulfield came into our service as shopman—he was placed behind the retail counter for the purpose of serving—on the 4th of April, about eleven o'clock in the morning, I cleared the two tills of the

silver in them; but previous to doing so, I prepared myself with 30s. which were three half-crowns, sixteen shillings, and thirteen sixpence—I had marked them—I placed them in the tills—after that, I went to my opposite neighbours, Messrs. Barber and Jupp, the silversmith's, from whence I had a very clear view of the shop—I left the prisoner Caulfield and my son, in the shop—there were from twenty to thirty persons went in, I should suppose—I went to my shop at two o'clock, and sent Caulfield out of the way, but previous to doing that, I had prepared myself with 30s. more, in marked money—I took all the silver out of the tills—there were two half-crowns marked—one half-crown, and in all, 1l. 8s. 6d.—I took that out, and put in six half-crowns, thirteen shillings, and four sixpences—they were marked with the same mark as those placed in at eleven o'clock, but it was not the same money,—I think it was not the same in again—after this I remained in the shop, and counting-house a little while, and sent my son up to dinner—I remained there till he came down, then I went up to dinner myself—I did not see Ash come to the shop—I did not know him at all.

COURT. Q. Was the 28s. 6d., which you took out at two o'clock, all marked? A. There were two half-crowns marked, a half-crown not me asked, nine shillings marked, seven shillings not marked, seven sixpence not marked, three sixpences marked.

MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Did the policeman show you some marked money afterwards? A. Yes, two shillings and a sixpence—I cannot tell whether that was put in at eleven o'clock or two o'clock—there were at least, twenty or thirty customers went in between eleven o'clock and two o'clock.

HENRY RUCK . I am the prosecutor's son. I was serving in the shop on the 4th of April, from eleven o'clock till two o'clock—I served now and then—Caulfield principally served the customers—I gave 2d., and one 6d. change, from the till—that was all I gave between eleven o'clock and ten o'clock—I do not know the parties I gave it to—I did not see Ash come in between eleven o'clock and two o'clock—I saw a man with a ship, but I do not believe it was Ash—I went up to dinner a little after two o'clock, and came down in about forty minutes—during the time I was there no one but I and the prisoner could have got to the tills.

JAMES JAMES (police-constable S 67.) I was watching at Messrs, Rucks on the 4th of April—I first began at a quarter before twelve o'clock, and watched till two o'clock—I saw about twenty people go in—Caulfield served them—no one went to the till but Caulfield and the last witness—I watched again after two o'clock—I had a full view of the counter in which the till was—if any one bad gone to it I must have seen them—I saw Ash go in—he went on the right hand side of the counter to look at some bacon—Caulfield came round the counter and cut three rashers of bacon which I have got—Caulfield returned behind the counter, and Ash went to the counter—I took more notice of Ash than of Caulfield—when Ash came to the counter, Caulfield was behind it, and he gave some coin to Ash, but I could not see what—he pulled out the till, and I saw some money pass—I could not see what—I did not see Ash lay down any money—I was in a position to see—he might have put a coin on the counter, but I did not see it—upon Ash going out, I followed him a little distance from the shop—I then spoke to him, and asked what he had there—he said, "Some bacon"—I asked what he gave for it—he said, "4d."—I said, "With what coin?"—he said, "A shilling"—I said, "Are

you sure you gave a shilling?"—he said, "Yes"—I took him to the station, and found on him two shillings and sixpence marked money, and 7 1/2d. in copper—nothing passed as to where he got it—he said something before the inspector, which I did not hear—that was the marked money which I afterwards showed to Mr. Ruck.

EDMUND NORTH . I am shopman to Messrs. Barbey and Jupp. I watched Messrs. Ruck's shop on the 4th of April—I saw Ash go in there—I had a view of the counters and tills—if any persons went to the tills I could see them—I watched from half-past eleven o'clock to three or four o'clock—I saw no person go to the tills besides Caulfield and the lad—I saw Ash go into the shop—I had seen him several times before that day—he did not go into the shop till about a quarter past two o'clock—I am quite positive he is the person—he went to the right hand side of the counter to look at some bacon—Caulfield came round the counter to serve him—Caulfield then returned to the till, and appeared to me to put some money is he drew out the till—and then Ash came out of the shop—I told the constable, and he was taken—I was at the shop door when he was taken—I did not perceive Caulfield hand any thing over to Ash.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. You speak of from half-past eleven o'clock? A. Yes—Ash could not have got behind the counter without my seeing him.
JOHN RUCK . This two shillings and sixpence is part of my marked money—I watched the shop from eleven till two o'clock.
Caulfield's Defence. Henry Ruck served Ash twice—I attended him the third time he came in.

MR. CLARKSON to HENRY ROCK. Q. Is this the sort of ship that the person brought in? (producing one.) A. I believe it is—I cannot say that Ash did not bring it in, but I do not believe he was the person—I my recollection points to a different person, but I will not swear he was not the me.
Ash. I am the person who took the ship in—the policeman did not tel you that I said to him, that the bacon I had been to purchase, was for a riend in the Marshalsea, named Roberts.
JAMES JAMES . He did not tell me so, but he mentioned it to the Magistrate, who sent an officer to inquire there.
COURT to HENRY RUCK. Q. Did you give in the course of that day two shillings and sixpence? A. All I gave was 6d. 2d.

Q. You saw some persons come with a ship like that into the shop? A. Yes—he purchased some goods of me—I think a 1/4 lb. of butter, and two gga—I do not recollect what they came to—I did not give two shillings a change—only 6d. and 2d.

JURY to JOHN RUCK. Q. Was the money counted after Ash was apprehended? A. It was—there was then 1l. 11s. 6d. in the till—it was five half-crowns marked, (one less than I put in); two not marked; mine shillings, marked; five not marked—the increase of copper was not more the 5s.—an hour and a half elapsed before I counted the money—I did not ount the copper.
COURT. Q. What would be an ordinary receipt from eleven to twelve o'clock? A. I should think at least 40s.

JURY. Q. Did you stay in the counting-house when your son went up to diner? A. I was there part of the time—I saw a man go in with a ship a little after eleven o'clock, but I should certainly say it was not the prisoner Ash—I had been watching in an opposite shop, just inside the door-way, which islevated three steps, so that we had a complete view—during the

time that Ash came my son was at dinner, and I was there—I cannot say that I saw him come in—I do not remember seeing him come in particularly—I could see in the counting-house what passed in the shop—I did not know Ash was apprehended till the officer came and told me—I do not mean that my eye was on the shop all the time, because I know that others were watching the shop.
Ash. I was examined five times—there was a person named Rickasby there each time with Mr. Ruck—he stated that he would give Mr. Ruck 50l. to prosecute me.
JOHN RUCK . I do not know a person of that name—this is the first I have heard of it—no one had said any thing to influence me in doing this.

1372.
CHARLES CAULFIELD was again indicted
for embezzlement.

MARY WILLIAMS . On the 4th of April I was servant to Mr. Hick, of No. 149, High-street, Borough, next door but one to Mr. Ruck. On the morning I paid the prisoner a bill of 8s. 7d., which my master owed to Mr. Ruck—I gave him three half-crowns, one shilling, and one pennyhe signed my book, which I kept for that purpose—it was as near to half-past eleven o'clock as I can recollect—I did not see what he did with the money.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you sure as to the time? A. Yes; I remember the time I went from home; I had no particular reason for it—I had looked at the clock when I left home—I paid him, and he marked the book after I paid him.
MR. CHAMBERS. Q. You looked at the clock when you left home; A. Yes; it was very little after eleven o'clock—I went to the green-grocess and then to Mr. Ruck's, and got home before twelve o'clock.

HENRY RUCK . I saw Williams come to the shop—she put down three half-crowns, one shilling, and one penny, and gave the book to Caulfield—I saw him take the money, but I did not see him put it any where—I only took two-pence, and six-pence out of the till that morning.

Cross-examined. Q. How near were you to him? A. Nearer the I am to you—I was looking at him, but not particularly—I Caulfield looking at him to see what he was doing—you may call it watching—I saw him take up the money—I turned my back to him immediately money was put on the counter—and said to be servant "Good morning," as she went out of the shop—I did not see any thing pass between then from the time he took up the money till I bid her good morning—he went to the desk with the book in his hand, and then gave her the books, and took up the money—the money was laid down, and then he signed the book, then gave it her and took up the money—my uncle Cornelias is my father's partner—he is not here—he is alive—the person who receives money puts it down in the book, and he ought to place the money in the till—the prisoner was taken up that very day, a little before four o'clock—this was at half-past eleven o'clock—I do not think he has ✗ever paid to my father, or to my uncle Cornelius money that he had received—my uncle was not in the house that day—the prisoner might have accounted to me for money but I do not recollect any instance—I never knew that he did to Mr. Cornelius—he was searched in my father's counting-house-at the time he was taken up, and his box was searched—I was not present.
COURT. Q. Will you turn to the entry of that day? A. Yes, it is marked in the prisoner's writing. "Hicks, paid, 8s. 7d."
MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Did he ever account to you for mo✗es he had
received, and kept in his possession? A. No; the servant placed the money on the counter.

COURT. Q. Is there an account of the day's transactions up to the time he was taken? A. Yes 15s. 11 1/2d. is the whole of what he states he received—I do not know that I made any entries in this book that day—here is an entry of bills received.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you see the prisoner enter that money of Wil
liams in the book? A. He was writing something in the book.
COURT. Q. Was he called upon that day of account for the 8s. 7d.? A. I do not know that he was.

COURT to JOHN RUCK. Q. Was there not 8s. 7d. of unmarked money in that till at two o'clock? A. There was one half-crown, nine shillings, and three six-pences unmarked—but there were two half-crowns marked in it, and no money large for which half a crown could have been given to change.

MR. CHAMBERS. Q. What was his duty? did he account to you in the evening, and pay you the money? A. No—there was no other way of doing it, but placing the money in the till, except in a large account of 3l. or 4l.—he was bound to enter in the book those account that had not been paid at the time.
Sixth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1373.
GEORGE SPINKS was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of May, 1 cask, value 6s., the goods of
John Whale.
MARY WHALE . I live in Thompson's buildings, Red-cross-street, Borough. My husband's name is John—we missed a cask on Saturday evening last—I think this is it—it was in the yard, full of water.
Prisoner. As I was coming from my work, I saw it he—I took it home, and was going to find the owner.

ROBERT PEARMAN (police-constable M 184.) On Saturday morning last, between one and two o'clock, I was on duty in Mint-street, and saw the prisoner trying to get into a lodging-house—they refused him, he having this cask in his possession—I went to see what it was—he said he brought it from Greenwich, that his brother gave it him, and it was new, but I found it an old cask, and it was wet inside, as if recently emptied.
Prisoner. I went across to the policeman, and said, "Here is a cask I picked up, will you take care of it"—he looked at it with his bull's eye, and then told me to go to the station-house.
ROBERT PEARMAN . No, quite the contrary—I went across to him, and I had no bull's eye—I never carry one.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1374.
MARGARET GORDON, alias Sugden
, was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of April 1 shawl, value 6s. 6d., the goods of
Daniel Smith.
DANIEL SMITH . I live in Kent-street, Borough, and am a butcher. I had this shawl safe on the morning of the 15th of April, in my parlour.

GEORGE SMITH . I am the prosecutor's son. On the 15th of April, the prisoner came to my father's parlour, and sent me for the key of the back shed—she was the servant next door—as I was coming back with the key, I met her going out of the back-door, with the shawl—she was not very drunk—she had had a little.

MARY ANN ASKEW . I am housekeeper to Mr. Smith. This shawl is his—George told me that the prisoner had gone out with the shawl—I ran after her, and took her with it—I think she was in liquor—I knew her by living a servant next door—I asked her to give it to me—she would not.
Prisoner. She is unfortunate like myself, and we lived in one house together for a month—being in liquor, I suppose I took the shawl—I have taken her things to wear many times.
MARY ANN ASKEN . I never lived with hershe never took my things to wear.

GUILTY .* Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.
Fifth Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1375.
FRANCIS FOOT was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of April, 100lbs. weight of iron, value 5s., the goods of
Edward Henry Chantler, in a barge, on a navigable river.

JOSEPH JOHN LEWIS . I am a Thames police-surveyor. On the morning of the 11th of April, I was in Guildford-street, Southwark, and saw a boy assisting the prisoner with a bag on his back—I went towards them—the prisoner threw the bag down and ran away—I pursued and brought him back—I looked into the bag, and saw it contained this iron which I now produce—also some iron rollers and other iron—I asked where he brought it from—he said he had taken it or picked it up (I am not certain which) from Bankside—this was at eight o'clock in the morning as near as could be—he told me he was going to sell it either in the Mint or in the Borough—Mr. Sutton came up while I was standing along-side the prosecutor's barge, and said, "This fencing was torn from the front of my house"—I walked up to Mr. Sutton's, and found the rails had been torn out, and the iron fencing corresponded in colour and size, with the pieces of bars in the bag—this iron roller was in the bag, and I found some similar to this on board the barge, which is Mr. Chantler's, and was about 100 yards from Mr. Sutton's railings.

EDWARD HENRY CHANTLER . I had a barge lying at Bankside, on the Thames, near the shore, under the wharf. I cannot say whether I had such a roller as this on board—I have no other piece like it—there was a quantity of iron in the barge—I cannot say whether the roller was there.

JAMES BENBOW . I am an iron-founder, and live at Bankside. On Sunday morning, the 10th of April, I was by the side of Mr. Chantler's barge—I took particular notice of this roller being on the head of the barge—I had some thought of buying it, and when it was shown to me again I was positive it was the one I saw on board the barge—the policeman and I looked over the iron in the barge, and found another roller like it, but I can swear this one was in the barge on Sunday morning—I did not see the other roller on that occasion—I noticed this particularly on the first occasion.

Prisoner's Defence. Mr. Lewis met me, and asked me where I was going—I said, to the corner of St. George's church, and a man gave it me to carry—I was to wait there till the man came—he said, "You must come with me, that iron is stolen"—I gave him the bag and ran away—he then took me to the office—he did not take me near Mr. Sutton's house—he took me in a boat, and rowed me up the river, and then down to the Thames Police—he took me down to Barelay's brew house and down Park-street—Mr. Sutton said at the office, that the fencing came from the front of his house, but he did not see me before.
JOSEPH JOHN LEWIS . Mr. Sutton saw it by the side if the barge at Bankside.
JOSEPH SUTTON . I saw it there, but I did not see the prisoner at the time.

Prisoner. He took me to the Thames Police, and then said he would go down and make inquiries—a lad of the name of price was taken with me, and he could say that he never showed it to any body till he got to the office—it was 600 yards from the place that I was taken.

ROBERT PRICE . On Monday, the 11th of April, about eight o'clock, I was passing Park-street—the prisoner was sitting on the seat of public-house—he asked me to give him a life up, which I did—the officer and a gentleman came up and took us—I was taken up the river and then down below to the office—I went on with another officer down Park-street, and to Horse-shoe-alley-stairs—the prisoner was behind—whether he stopped or not I cannot tell.

GUILTY .* Aged 15.—
Transported for Seven Years. (There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

1376.
WILLIAM BRAYDON was indicted
for embezzlement.

JOHN CHARLES BRINE . I live at the sign of the Saxe Coburg, in the Old Kent-road. The prisoner was my pot-boy—on the 9th of May I gave him into custody—he was employed by me to receive money paid for beer as it was delivered—Mr. Lawless's servant called for beer on the 30th of April—I had directions to send a pint of gin to Mr. Lawless—I never received the money from the prisoner—I made out bills for the prisoner to deliver to him—my wife was in the habit of settling with his sometimes—whether she received it or not I do not know.

1377.
JOHN DAVIS was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

ALEXANDER LEE . I was a practitioner in medicine, and live in Crown-square, Southwark. On the 1st of April the prisoner came to my house, and asked if I was Dr. Lee—he said he was sent by the captain of the Dundee, naming Captain Wishar; that there was a package on board directed to me, and it must be fetched before ten o'clock the next morning, otherwise it would be landed, and incur expense—I asked him if he had seen the package—he said yes, with my full name on it—I said, I supposed he expected something for it, and offered him 2d.; he objected, and said he must have 6d., and it was his privilege, as the pilot-boy, to have that—I have not received any such parcel—it was on the faith of his representing there was such a parcel that I gave it him.
JOHN WISHART . I am Captain of the Dundee steam-boat. The prisoner had nothing to do with me—I never saw him in my life—I never had such a parcel as he describes for Mr. Lee.

JOHN BRADY (police-constable K 68.) I took the prisoner from Dr. Garmutz—he stated he came from Gravesend with a person, to bring up a boat loaded with timber, and he had duped six or seven; and what could they do? they could give him but three months, and he did not care a d—n for that.
Prisoner's Defence. I did it through distress—I had been walking about a long time, and had nothing.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1378.
GEORGE STAINER and
HENRY JORDAN were indicted for
a misdemeanor.
MESSRS. CHAMBERS and SHEA conducted the Prosecution.

ANNA MARIA COLWELL . I am the wife of a tobacconist, and live at Bridge-house-place, Newington, Surrey. Stainer came to our shop on the 14th of April, for 1/4oz. of tobacco—it came to 1d.—he gave me a sixpence—I had not change enough—he said he would have 1/2oz.—I gave him 4d., and took his sixpence, and laid it at the corner of the till—Langley then came in—I took the till out, and showed him the sixpence—it was a bad one.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. How long elapsed from the time of your taking it and the officer coming in? A. I should think not a minute—my husband was out at the time—there had been other customers in the shop, but only Stainer brought a sixpence—when my husband went out there was silver in the till; but I put the silver I take in a corner of the till, to show my husband what I have taken in his absence—there is no division in it; but I took the till out, and showed the officer the sixpence in the corner—I had put no mark on it before.
MR. SHEA. Q. Did you shut the till hard? A. I do not remember—I do not think that one sixpence could jump out, and another jump in.

MARY EVANS . I live with Mr. Budden, who keeps the Rose. I saw Stainer about five o'clock, on the 14th of April—he offered me a sixpence—I just laid it in the till—there were other sixpences there—the officer came in at one door as the prisoner went out—he asked me for it—I had just laid the sixpence out of my fingers—I gave it him—I am sure it was the same sixpence—it was just in one corner of the till—I had not lost sight of it.

Cross-examined. Q. Is yours a till that draws out? A. Yes; we put the money through a notch in the counter—when I drew it out I saw a good deal of silver in the till—I had just laid the sixpence out of my hand when the officer came, but not out of my sight—all the silver was in my sight, and that among the rest.
JURY. Q. Had you shut the till? A. No, I had nearly shut it.

MARIA LOUIBA JAQUES . I am a tobacconist, and live in Lambeth. On the 14th of April, Stainer came for a 1/4oz. of tobacco—it came to 1d.—he gave me a sixpence—I gave him change—I put the sixpence into the till—there was no other sixpence in it—there were shillings and half-crowns—in a short time Langley came in—I showed him the sixpence—it was a bad one—I gave it to him.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you always attend to the shop? A. Yes—I had sold a good many cigars—some are 3d. each—I dare say I had sold some that afternoon—when I gave the officer the sixpence I looked in the till, and there was no other sixpence there—we must have taken some and passed them again.
EDWARD LANGLEY (police-constable A 11.) I watched the two prisoners on the 14th of April—they went to Colwell's shop—Stainer went in, and Jordan waited ten yards off—he came out—I

went in and got a sixpence—I followed the prisoners to the Rose, in Westminster-road—Stainer went in, Jordan was about five yards off—Stainer came out, and they joined again—I went in and got a sixpence there—they went a little way on to West-minister-road, then turned back and went to the New Cut, to Jaques"—Stainer went in—Jordan remained a few yards off—Stainer came out—I went in and got this 6d.—they joined again—I followed them, got assistance, and took them.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you ever known Stainer to be in trouble before? A. Yes, in Queen-square, but he was discharged immediately.

STAINER—
GUILTY . Aged 22.

JORDAN—
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined One Year.

1379.
JOHN THOMAS was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
MR. CHAMBERS conducted the Prosecution.

WILLIAM HAYMAN (police-constable B 136.) I went to Mr. Stanford's shop in Pimlico, and took the prisoner—Mr. Stanford said he had offered him a bad shilling, which be gave to me—he was taken to a police-office and discharged—Mr. Stanford is not here, but he charged the prisoner with it in his presence.

CHARLES BUNDOCK . I live at Mr. Priest's dining-rooms, Lowere Marsh, Lambeth. On the 16th of April the prisoner came there, about twenty minutes past ten o'clock—he asked for 1lb. of buttock-of-beef—a young woman cut it, and he gave her a crown-piece—I saw it was bed—it was returned to him—he had no more money, and went out—I followed him, and saw him go to another shop, eight or ten house down York-street.
Prisoner. I never was in the shop at all. Witness. I am positive he was—he had a snuff-coloured coat on.

SARAH MOSLEY . I am the wife of Mr. Mosley, of Granby-street. On the 16th of April, the prisoner came for half a quarters loaf, and half a quartern of flour—he gave me a five-shilling-piece—I gave him 4s. 4d. change—I laid the five-shilling-piece down, and the moment he went out, I looked, and found it was bed—a man ran up to the door, and asked if a man had passed had money—I kept the prisoner in sight till I gave him to a policeman.

WILLIAM BURROWES . I am a carpenter. I met with Mr. Priest's servant—I followed the prisoner and another man—they went on to Mr. Mosley's—I saw the prisoner go in there, and assisted in stopping him till the officer came.

JAMES NEWMAN . I am called by Burrowes, and took the prisoner—the flour and loaf were on the counter—he chuched 4 1/2d. on the counter, and said, "I sha'nt take that, I have passed 1s."—Mrs. Mosley gave me this crown-piece.

SARAH MOSLEY . I gave him 4s. 4 1/2d., and when he came back he threw down 4 1/2d., and said he had passed 1s.—I do not know what became of the shillings I gave him, unless he threw in the road—it is a very dirty place.
JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of coin to the Mint. This is a very bad crown-piece.

Prisoner. I went into the shop for half a quartern loaf and half a quar
tern of flour—there was another person came out of the shop just as I went in—I gave but 1s., and had but 4 1/2d. change

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined One Year.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY JUNE 13, 1836.
